dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Spartan boy of maybe eight is beaten by another boy of the same age.

dialogues.speaker: DILIOS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Manufactured by 300 years of Spartan warrior society to create the finest soldiers the world has ever known, the Agoge, as it is called, forces the boy to fight... Time slows: Blood sprays from his mouth as he is struck again and again and again.

dialogues.speaker: DILIOS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Starves them, forces them to steal and if necessary, to kill. The boy stands out of breath, his body gleaming with sweat. Blood drips from his fists.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A boy of eleven is tied at the wrists. His face pressed against a column as a handful of muscular, grim-faced soldiers watch. His back already bleeding as he is whipped again. His face is stone, emotionless.

dialogues.speaker: DILIOS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: By rod and lash the boy was punished, taught to show no pain, taught to show no mercy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blue light crouches on black rocks. Snow drifts, defying gravity. A hand, blistered by the cold, clamors and climbs. The hand belongs to the boy, now twelve.

dialogues.speaker: DILIOS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Constantly tested, tossed into the wild. Left to pit his wits and will against nature's fury. Though starving and freezing, there is a nobility in the boy's gaze. Though his body shakes, his homespun tunic no match for the bitter cold, he is defiant. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DILIOS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: He'd survived on roots, bugs and rodents, and now he was freezing to death. It was his initiation -.. his time in the wild... for he would return to his people a Spartan, or not at all. The boy stumbles into a clearing surrounded on three sides by the stone faces of the canyon. He stands, peering into the gathering din. He grips the spear, lightly moving it back and forth from hand to hand. The spear is little more than a child's toy, a sharpened stick. The boy's eyes search the tree line, the darkness moves... shadow gliding on muscle and sinew.

dialogues.speaker: DILIOS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: He hears a low growl. The hair on his arms stands up. Cold, hungry, defenseless. He is prey. It tracks the boy and he knows it.

dialogues.speaker: DILIOS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: The wolf begins to circle the boy. Claws of black steel, fur as dark as night, eyes glowing red... jewels from the pit of Hades itself. The WOLF breathes in misty clouds, the swirling snow printed against its black fur. GROWLING as it moves closer, circling, hunting. WE SEE: The boy from between a narrow cut in the rock, just large enough for him to squeeze through. His eyes are calm. His body has stopped shaking. He sees the crack in the black stone, and turns slowly, almost casually, toward it.

dialogues.speaker: DILIOS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: The giant wolf... sniffing... drooling... savoring the scent of the meal to come. Does the boy run? Does he cower? Does he cry? No... not this boy. He is calm. The beast pauses, loading to spring. The boy leaps through the cut in the rock. The WOLF pounces, HOWLING as it charges! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Its jaws are inches from the boy's neck as he falls backward through the wound in the rock. The beast's body is stopped cold in the tight space. Thrashing, the wolf is pinned by the unforgiving stone. The boy rises slowly.

dialogues.speaker: DILIOS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: It is not fear that grips him, only a heightened sense of things. The snow drifts around his feet. TIME SLOWS. The wolf's jaws GNASH! The boy exhales slowly.

dialogues.speaker: DILIOS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: The cold air in his lungs. The leafless poplars moving against the coming night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His eyes look back toward the wolf, he nods his respect, then raises his spear.

dialogues.speaker: DILIOS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: His hands are steady, his form | perfect. The clouds part, and the just rising crescent moon, warm on the horizon, casts a shadow of the angry wolf on the cold rock. The boy sets himself, then strikes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Spartan helmet lands heavily in the snow-covered courtyard, followed by the thick-muscled frame of a SPARTAN GENERAL, who, after going to his knees, bows his head to the snow. Standing before him is the boy, draped in the freshly dressed pelt of a black wolf. As others enter the courtyard, they too fall to their knees, * SHOUTING! Spears are raised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CRIES of joy and reverence are heard as the boy raises his chin. é.

dialogues.speaker: DILIOS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: So the boy, given up for dead, returns to his people, to sacred Sparta, a King...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dozens of SPARTAN HOPLITES sit and stand, transfixed by the agitated pacing Spartan whose fist is raised in dramatic punctuation. This is DILIOS (28), the storyteller. His gift. His curse. To conjure from his memory, from his imagining, that which men forgot, but need to remember.

dialogues.speaker: DILIOS
dialogues.text: ... Our King! LEONIDAS! The men visible in the firelight, and countless others in the darkness beyond... POUND their shields in unison and cry as one.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: A HUSH falls over the band of Spartan warriors, their faces hard, bodies oiled for war. All listen as Dilios pauses. His voice lowers.

dialogues.speaker: DILIOS
dialogues.text: It has been more than thirty years since the wolf and the winter cold, and now, as then, a beast approaches, patient, and confident, savoring the meal to come. But this beast is made of men and horses, swords and spears. Dilios scans his audience. The light from the fire moves across the capes of crimson and helmets of bronze. Dilios is a grim orator. His scarred and ruddy face bears witness to his own story.

dialogues.speaker: DILIOS
dialogues.text: It is an army of slaves, vast beyond imagining, ready to devour tiny Greece. Ready to snuff out the world's one hope for reason and justice. There is brewing anger in the eyes of his listeners. Dilios sets his gaze to the fire.

dialogues.speaker: DILIOS
dialogues.text: The beast approaches, and it was King Leonidas himself who provoked it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colorful Persian BANNERS SNAP! Pulling taut in the wind. The earth is overturned under the charge of the Company of War horses. ARCHERS, SWORDSMEN and SHADOWED FORMS. Riders all covered in thin patterned robes of gold and blue, embroidered silks, braided belts with long- shouldered capes flowing. Into the sunless dry scrub and wood where the path curves dark and cool they ride on... They ride on!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No wall surrounds Sparta. The buildings have no flowered columns, no carved arches, no fluted gables, no recorded dates and wreathed tributes to the dead. No, this is Sparta. This is the simple elegance of an unadorned shelter. WE SEE: The mounted Persian column appear in the stillness of the morning. A massive black horse rears and drops its frame, dust curling around its hooves. A PERSIAN MESSENGER with scarred face and sharpened teeth of gold settles the horses. His 20 men-at-arms fill in along his side.

dialogues.speaker: MESSENGER
dialogues.text: I bring word from the Great Xerxes, Conqueror of all the world. The Spartan SENTRIES approach, slowly. One steps forward and sniffs the air, mocking the Persian force.

dialogues.speaker: SENTRY
dialogues.text: Could we offer you a bath, Persian? WE HEAR: Laughter from the other Spartans standing nearby.

dialogues.speaker: SENTRY
dialogues.text: I am sure our women have a perfume you'll find agreeable. The Persian Messenger pulls at the leather reins of his mount, sinking the bit into the horse's foaming mouth.

dialogues.speaker: MESSENGER
dialogues.text: Greek arrogance! It will be the death of you all. If it were not for diplomacy, I would rip the breath from your lungs. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: i

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He turns the horse in a tight circle and looks out at the CITIZENS of Sparta who are milling about, Helot farmers, masons, women and children watch as the Messenger glares down at them.

dialogues.speaker: MESSENGER
dialogues.text: Show me your King.

dialogues.speaker: SENTRY
dialogues.text: Our King is a busy man. The Persian Messenger reaches into a waxed canvas bag that lays across the horse's neck. WE SEE: The jeweled crowns of conquered nations. The Messenger lifts at the rope running through the bone- white eye sockets of a half-dozen human skulls.

dialogues.speaker: MESSENGER
dialogues.text: These Kings were busy men once. The Messenger kicks at his horse, holding the skulls and royal headdresses for all to see.

dialogues.speaker: MESSENGER
dialogues.text: Be afraid. Sparta will burn to the ground. Only the word of King Leonidas can save it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WE HEAR: The FLUTTER of HUMMINGBIRDS against the pale stone walls covered, thick and dark, with ivy and wild lilac. KING LEONIDAS (40), strong and lean, a king, a warrior, a father, rolls on the ground in simulated combat with his six-year-old boy, PLEISTARCHOS.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: Remember, my son. The more you sweat here the less you will bleed in battle. The boy dives at his father, missing the King's legs.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: Follow your instincts. Leonidas smiles.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: Act without hesitation. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Again the boy tackles and they tumble over each other into the soft grass.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: Hesitation creates fear. They wrestle on... continuing one of the ancient rituals of father and son.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: Fear is always a constant. But accepting it will make you stronger. Leonidas spins and grabs the boy's leg, pulling him to the ground. Leonidas looks across the garden to see his wife, QUEEN GORGO (28), with her athletic frame, watching the two of them.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: In the end, a Spartan's true strength is the warriors next to him. Give respect and honor and it will be returned to you. Leonidas roils the boy to his back.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: First, you fight with your head. WE SEE: A Spartan, Leonidas' CAPTAIN (45), broad- shouldered and fiercely loyal, speaking to Gorgo near the stone pillars of the compound. Pleistarchos arches, slips free and reverses to his father's back. .

dialogues.speaker: GORGO
dialogues.text: Then you fight with your heart. Gorgo lifts Pleistarchos off of his father.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: GORGO
dialogues.text: Your father has things to attend to. Leonidas rises to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: (to Pleistarchos) Bring me my sword. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The boy nods and goes.

dialogues.speaker: GORGO
dialogues.text: A Persian messenger awaits you. Pleistarchos returns with a simple short sword of iron, its handle inlaid carnelian and amber. Leonidas arms himself and leans down, kissing his son on the forehead.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: Do not forgot today's lesson.

dialogues.speaker: PLEISTARCHOS
dialogues.text: Respect and honor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Persians wait in the full heat of the sun, watched by Spartan guards. Free women and children pass the narrow streets, carrying electrum vases, all shapes and sizes of glass and terra-cotta water vessels. THERON, 36, a Spartan Councilman with noble features, a body of lean muscles and piercing eyes, retired from the battlefield for a life in politics, stands and speaks freely with the Messenger from the East as Leonidas and Gorgo approach.

dialogues.speaker: GORGO
dialogues.text: Councilman, you have found yourself needed, for once. Theron allows the comment to disappear into the sounds of the market.

dialogues.speaker: THERON
dialogues.text: My King and Queen, I was just entertaining your guests.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: I am sure. Leonidas stands before the Persian Messenger.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: Before you speak, Persian, know that in Sparta everyone, even a king's messenger, is held accountable for the words of his voice. Now, what message do you bring? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: i

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The Messenger opens his great arms, palms to the azure sky.

dialogues.speaker: MESSENGER
dialogues.text: Earth and water! Leonidas narrows his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: You rode all the way from Persia for earth and water? The Persian holds to his message studying the King's face.

dialogues.speaker: GORGO
dialogues.text: Do not be coy or stupid, Persian. You can afford neither in Sparta. The Persian turns to Gorgo, never having been spoken to by a woman in this tone.

dialogues.speaker: MESSENGER
dialogues.text: What makes this woman think she can speak among men?

dialogues.speaker: GORGO
dialogues.text: Because only Spartan women give birth to real men. The Persian must swallow his pride along with the insult before his men.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: Let us walk to cool our tongues. Leonidas turns away, leaving the rest to follow the King's steps.

dialogues.speaker: MESSENGER
dialogues.text: If you value your lives over your complete annihilation, listen carefully, Leonidas. Xerxes conquers and controls everything that his eye rests upon. The Messenger throws a look to Gorgo and continues.

dialogues.speaker: MESSENGER
dialogues.text: He leads a force so massive it shakes the earth with its march. Its number so vast it drinks the rivers dry. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The Spartan bodyguards watch the Persians carefully.

dialogues.speaker: MESSENGER
dialogues.text: All the God-King Xerxes requires is this, a simple offering of earth and water. A token of Sparta's submission to the will of Xerxes. Leonidas stops in his tracks...

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: Submission...? That's a bit of a problem. Rumor has it the Athenians have already turned you down. And if those philosophers and boy lovers found that kind of nerve... Theron moves forward.

dialogues.speaker: THERON
dialogues.text: We must be diplomatic. Leonidas raises his hand.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: . And Spartans have their reputation to consider.

dialogues.speaker: MESSENGER
dialogues.text: Choose your next words carefully, Leonidas. They may be your last as king. Leonidas looks away from the Messenger's eyes and scans the Persian bodyguards, assessing their strength. TIME SLOWS for our King. He watches the freedoms of his people. WE HEAR: The sounds of CHILDREN'S LAUGHTER. The simple pure life each have built for themselves. The words "earth and water" form quietly on his lips. He looks to his Queen, mother of his child.

dialogues.speaker: TIME UNWRAPS --
dialogues.text: As Leonidas stares at the Messenger. In one motion the King draws his sword, bringing it to the Persian's neck. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MESSENGER
dialogues.text: Madman... you're a madman! The Spartan guards quickly follow their King and hold their weapons to the Persian force before them.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: Earth and water. Leonidas begins to back the Persian messenger up towards a deep open well.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: You'll find plenty of both down there.

dialogues.speaker: MESSENGER
dialogues.text: No man, Persian or Greek, no man threatens a messenger.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: You bring the crowns and heads of conquered kings to my city steps. You insult my Queen. You threaten my people with slavery and death. I've chosen my words carefully, Persian. I hear your message clearly. It is that of a war party! Leonidas touches his sword onto the dark flesh of the Messenger.

dialogues.speaker: MESSENGER
dialogues.text: This is blasphemy! Theron raises his hands in a desperate attempt to stop Leonidas.

dialogues.speaker: THERON
dialogues.text: This is madness. Leonidas has the messenger's heels hanging above the void of the well. The Persians eye the Spartans nervously. WE SEE: The sword lowering from the Persian's neck. Theron relaxes, thinking reason has prevailed. A warm wind plays against the King's robe. Leonidas looks at Gorgo, she nods, knowing full well what that nod brings to her King and Sparta. And with one great push against the Persian's chest...

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: Madness? This is Sparta! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The Messenger's body falls away... deep... deep into the circular chasm. Theron steps back as the Spartan men unleash their savagery. Persian after Persian follows the first, resting where even their faint cries for mercy cannot be heard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lit by the almost full moon, Leonidas climbs hard, with clenched teeth, the steep rock face inaccessible to most. A foot slips. Rocks come loose. His grip tightens and he climbs on, finally pulling himself and his sixty-pound leather satchel onto a small ledge where a cloaked figure stands. The WIND pushes and pulls the torchlight this way and that. This is an EPHOR, a priest of the old gods, deformed by breeding. His face and body are covered with boils and lesions. His eyes are bleached white under the hoods of black.

dialogues.speaker: DILIOS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: The Ephors. Priests to the Old Gods, inbred swine, more creature than man. Creatures whom even a king must bribe... and bed.

dialogues.speaker: EPHOR
dialogues.text: Welcome, Leonidas. We have been expecting you. The FIRE ROARS in protest at the end of the torch. The Ephor turns and begins to climb an impossible set of stairs hewn out of the rock of the mountain. Leonidas shoulders the satchel and starts after his ungracious host up the stairs, which circle around a finger of rock toward a simple stone temple that glows at the summit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oil lanterns cast a warm light on EIGHT EPHORS, all as decrepit as their brother, who stand around Leonidas as he hastily lays out his plan. At the center of the temple is a low stone box filled with fine sand used by the Ephors to sketch down that which is fleeting to man and even more fleeting to the Gods. Leonidas pulls a wooden block across the sand to smooth its surface. Then, with his finger, he begins to draw. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: The Persians claim their forces number in the millions. I hope, for our sake, they exaggerate. One of the Ephors interrupts the King, his arms crossed, his blistered face stern.

dialogues.speaker: EPHOR
dialogues.text: You insult the Gods with your arrogance, Leonidas. We are not a council of men. We serve the Gods, not the whim of a King. Before your plan is heard, what do you offer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leonidas is mid-line, drawing his battle plan in the sand. He looks up at the hooded figures. He lifts a finger slowly from the sand. He ducks the leather strap of his satchel and tosses it at the feet of the Ephors. The gold spills out onto the stone floor. Dipping his finger back into the sand, Leonidas sketches a primitive map.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: We will use our superior fighting skills and the terrain of Greece herself to destroy them. We will march North to the coast. I will...

dialogues.speaker: EPHOR
dialogues.text: It is August, Leonidas. The full moon approaches.

dialogues.speaker: EPHOR
dialogues.text: The sacred and ancient festival. Sparta wages no war at the time of the Carneia. Leonidas is desperate, almost angry. He searches the dead eyes of the Ephors.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: Sparta will burn! Her men will die at arms, and her women and children will be slaves or worse. This is not a campaign for land or riches. It is a fight for our very lives! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Leonidas plunges his finger back into the sand and draws a line running perpendicular to his line representing the coast.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: We will block the Persian coastal assault by replacing the great stone wall, built by the Phocians to protect Greece two hundred years ago, and funnel them into the mountain pass we call the Hot Gates. Leonidas holds his hands up in front of his face as if they are the Hot Gates themselves.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: In that narrow corridor their numbers will count for nothing. The King pounds his fist into his open hand.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: Xerxes' losses will be so great, his men so demoralized, he will have no choice but to abandon his campaign. The Ephors move uneasily, looking back and forth between each other. Leonidas is mystified by their silence.

dialogues.speaker: EPHOR
dialogues.text: We must consult the Oracle. Trust the Gods, Leonidas.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: I'd prefer you trust your reason. The Ephor snaps back at Leonidas, pointing a misshapen finger at the kneeling King.

dialogues.speaker: EPHOR
dialogues.text: Your blasphemies have cost us quite enough already. Don't compound them. We will consult the oracle. The Ephors turn away. Leonidas follows them. Carved into the stone, under a domed ceiling, is an altar. It is a stage fashioned to look like the hand of a God. In its palm, a beautiful YOUNG GIRL moves hypnotically. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Around the altar the Ephors stoke small fires which burn green with the smell of sulfur, careful not to breathe the smoke themselves, they retreat to the shadows.

dialogues.speaker: DILIOS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Diseased old mystics... worthless remnants of a time before Sparta's ascent from darkness... remnants of a senseless tradition. Tradition even Leonidas cannot defy, for he must respect the word of the Ephors. That is the law. Leonidas watches as the vapors engulf the girl. She begins to shake and convulse, her body thinly veiled by the sheerest of fabric. The firelight behind her reveals the beauty of her form and the tragedy of her plight.

dialogues.speaker: DILIOS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: - And no Spartan, subject or citizen, man or woman, slave or King, is above the law. Then, through the darkness -- DRUMS! The girl's eyes roll back. Her body heaves and writhes. She moans and drools, her hips thrusting, her chest heaving. She -- CRIES! Through her pleasure and pain. The beating of the drums quicken, as does the violence of her rapture. Her veil clings to her sweaty form until finally she CRIES out! DRUMS stop, and she collapses. After a moment, the Ephors run in extinguishing the fires. One of the Ephors leans close to the Oracle as another pulls a wooden block across the sand, erasing the King's plan.

dialogues.speaker: DILIOS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: The Ephors choose only the most beautiful Spartan girls to live among them as Oracles. Their beauty is their curse, for the old wretches have the needs of men... and souls as black as hell. Her breathing is shallow. The old Ephor can't resist letting his tongue lick across the Oracle's neck, tasting her salty skin, before he turns his deformed ear to her mouth, which whispers in trance. As he listens, he speaks in an ancient language spoken only by Ephors. She speaks as he translates. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: EPHOR
dialogues.text: Pray to the winds. Sparta will fall. All Greece will fall. Trust not in men. Honor the Gods. Honor the Carneia. Leonidas shows nothing. A WIND HOWLS through the columns of the open temple. He looks into the faces of the Ephors, then turns into the darkness and is gone.

dialogues.speaker: DILIOS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: The King's climb down is harder. Pompous inbred swine... worthless, diseased, rotten...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gold falls in showers. Printed onto the coins is the likeness of a Persian God or man.

dialogues.speaker: DILIOS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: - corrupt... The Ephors kneel, running their hands through the great pile of gold. Standing in the firelight, is Theron. At his side, a large PERSIAN, his body crisscrossed with chains and giant locks of ancient iron, tosses a handful of gold onto the pile. . Theron turns to the Persian.

dialogues.speaker: THERON
dialogues.text: Leonidas will not march. The word of the Oracle is final.

dialogues.speaker: PERSIAN
dialogues.text: What of your Spartan Council? Could they not vote to ignore these mystics' words.

dialogues.speaker: THERON
dialogues.text: The members of that Council are as superstitious as they are old. Your gold is well spent. When I am made ruler or all Greece and Sparta is its capital, her people and armies will serve the God King well.

dialogues.speaker: PERSIAN
dialogues.text: You have only to remove the Spartan Queen and its heir for your plan to be complete. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: THERON
dialogues.text: You need not instruct me in the course of my own treachery. This plan was born long before Xerxes turned his eye to Greece. It rose from my hatred of Leonidas’ Measured judgment... It rose from my envy of his skill in battle... It rose from my lust for the warmth of his young bride. Ail the hate in my soul will find itself manifested on his house, and his victories, his love, his freedom, his very blood will lie in ruin at my feet. Theron turns to the Ephors.

dialogues.speaker: THERON
dialogues.text: This is but a token. Great Xerxes gives his thanks, oh wise and holy Men. You are truly in the God King's favor now. The Persian smiles, his face adorned with gold piercings, his eyes pale blue.

dialogues.speaker: PERSIAN
dialogues.text: Yes, for when Sparta burns, you will bathe in gold. Fresh oracles will be delivered to you daily, from every corner of the empire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The waxing gibbous moon shines onto the stone floor of the King's bedroom. It is a second-story room overlooking a small courtyard, Beyond that, edged by moonlight, the roofs and houses of sleeping Sparta. Leonidas leans on the frame of his balcony doorway, unable to sleep. After a moment he sighs and moves to his bed, where his wife Gorgo sleeps soundly, the sheet down to her waist, revealing her strong feminine back, which shines with the warmth of August. Leonidas sits at the edge of the bed and lightly traces his finger along the contours of her body. She stirs, and now, sleepily, she stares up at him. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GORGO
dialogues.text: Your lips can finish what your fingers have started... Or has the Oracle robbed you of your desire as well?

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: It would take more than words of a drunken adolescent girl to rob me of my desire for you. apna Gorgo smiles. The curls of her black hair fall softly across her neck and collarbone.

dialogues.speaker: GORGO
dialogues.text: Then why so distant?

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: Because it seems, though a slave and captive of lecherous old men, the Oracle's words could set fire to all that I love. She reaches up to him, laying her hand to the side of his face.

dialogues.speaker: GORGO
dialogues.text: So that is why my King loses sleep and is forced from the warmth of his bed. Gorgo furrows her brow in mock concern.

dialogues.speaker: GORGO
dialogues.text: There's only one woman's words that should affect the mood of my husband... and those are mine. He smiles, if only briefly. He is in pain and she can see it.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: What must a King do to save his world, when the very laws he has sworn to protect, force him to do nothing? Gorgo sits up. She is tender, yet intense. She looks into his eyes for a moment, then her expression softens. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GORGO
dialogues.text: It is not a question of what a Spartan citizen should do, nor a husband, nor a King. Instead ask yourself, my dearest love, what should a free man do? He looks at her. They are close. The moment stretches and he smiles. They kiss and fall back onto the bed. This is love between a Spartan King and his Queen. Their skin is wet. Their mouths hunger. Their muscles flex. It is not soft. It is passion personified. They love as they live.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sky is pale and clear to the east as 300 Spartans hold rank in a field of golden wheat. Leonidas and his Captain walk past the familiar face of Dilios, who nods to his king.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: Is this all of them?

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: As you ordered. 300 with born sons to carry on their name. A Spartan named STELIOS (28), lean and hard-bodied, speaks up from the line of soldiers.

dialogues.speaker: STELIOS
dialogues.text: We are with you, sir, to the death. The Captain turns and barks at Stelios.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: Hold your tongue, boy! Or I'll take you at your word. Leonidas makes eye contact with Stelios, then points to a young Spartan, with the soft face of a child near the rear of the pack.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: He is your own and too young to have felt a woman's warmth. Leonidas stands before the baby-faced warrior.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: I have others to replace him. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The Captain stands next to his King, and glances into the eyes of his son, ASTINOS (18).

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: He is as brave and ready as any. No younger than we were the first time you stood next to me in battle.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: You are a good friend, but a better Captain, there is not. Leonidas places his hand on the Captain's shoulder, as if to mark his selfless act. In the morning light, a group of COUNCILMEN are led forward by Theron.

dialogues.speaker: ELDER COUNCILMAN
dialogues.text: My good King, the Oracle has spoken. The group stands before Leonidas, trying to gain his attention.

dialogues.speaker: COUNCILMAN
dialogues.text: The Ephors have spoken. There must be no march. Leonidas continues to view his men with a disciplined eye.

dialogues.speaker: THERON
dialogues.text: The law, my Lord. The Spartan Army must not go to War.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: Nor shall it. You worry over nothing. Theron and the councilmen view the assembly of warriors.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: I have issued no such orders. These 300 are my personal bodyguards. Our army will stay in Sparta. Leonidas looks away from his 300, to his Queen and child who have now joined the group.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: We'll head North. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Gorgo pulls her son into her hip.

dialogues.speaker: GORGO
dialogues.text: The Hot Gates. Leonidas looks at his family.

dialogues.speaker: ELDER COUNCILMAN 4
dialogues.text: What do we do? :

dialogues.speaker: THERON
dialogues.text: What can we do?

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: You will listen to your queen in my absence. The throne of Sparta rests with her. Leonidas lifts his shield and looks back at his 300 men. The Captain nods that his men are ready. Leonidas calls back to the Spartan Councilmen.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: What can you do? Sparta will need * sons. Leonidas moves toward his men, to begin their long march North.

dialogues.speaker: GORGO
dialogues.text: Spartan! Leonidas turns to his wife's voice.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: Yes, my lady. The Queen walks to him, lifting from her neck the simple leather necklace, attached is a wolf fang. Her husband's first boyhood enemy.

dialogues.speaker: GORGO
dialogues.text: Come back with your shield... or on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leonidas bows slightly, as she passes the necklace over his head.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: Yes, my lady.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are no tears from her eyes, nor trembling in his voice. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DILIOS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Goodbye, my love. He doesn't say it. There is no room for softness, not in Sparta. No place for weakness. Leonidas and his 300 start to march from Sparta.

dialogues.speaker: DILIOS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Only the hard and strong may call themselves Spartans. The King knows he will never see her again. He will never see Sparta again. They march on!

dialogues.speaker: DILIOS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Only the hard. Only the strong. *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On a distant blade of rock, a LONE FIGURE, hobbled and bent, follows the Spartans as they move across the golden fields.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WE HEAR: the sound of twin FLUTES and goat hide sandals against soil. In silence, they march over the sharp rocks and earth, looming steadily, weaving a small shapeless mass of men North. DILIOS (V.0.) Lot * We march. For our lands. For our families. For our freedoms. On the broken ridgeline more men appear, other pockets of strong Hoplites from city-states that have heard the call to war.

dialogues.speaker: DILIOS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Noisy Arcadians greet us with noisy complaints. Leonidas leads his men and greets the Arcadians.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: Daxos, a pleasant surprise. DAXOS, a tree trunk of a man, circular shield strapped to his back, leads the Arcadian force. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DAXOS
dialogues.text: This morning's full of surprises, Leonidas. His men look at the small Spartan numbers and begin to murmur among themselves.

dialogues.speaker: ARCADIANS
dialogues.text: We have been tricked... There can't be more than a few hundred of them... This is a surprise...

dialogues.speaker: DAXOS
dialogues.text: Silence. The men settle and listen... listen carefully to the words that will come.

dialogues.speaker: DAXOS
dialogues.text: We were told Sparta was on the warpath! We were eager to join forces.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: If it is blood you seek, you are welcome to join us. Daxos scans the Spartans, counting quickly the rows of men, unmoving under the weight of their armor as if carved from the mountain itself.

dialogues.speaker: DAXOS
dialogues.text: But you bring only this handful against Xerxes? I see I was wrong to expect Sparta's commitment to at least match our own! Leonidas sits atop a smooth, moss-covered stone.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: Doesn't it? Leonidas glances to the Arcadians.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: You there. What is your profession? A small-framed ARCADIAN steps forward.

dialogues.speaker: ARCADIAN
dialogues.text: I am a potter, sir. Leonidas points to another. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: i
i

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: And you, Arcadian. What is your profession? Another Arcadian responds from group.

dialogues.speaker: ARCADIAN
dialogues.text: A sculptor, sir. Leonidas points again to the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: And you?

dialogues.speaker: ARCADIAN
dialogues.text: A blacksmith. Again the King points.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: You?

dialogues.speaker: ARCADIAN
dialogues.text: A baker. Leonidas stands, turning to his 300.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: Spartans! What is your profession? From the silent mass of Spartan muscle, 300 spears and swords are raised to the sky, a collective battle cry exits each, thunder and fire that spits forth from their bellies.

dialogues.speaker: SPARTANS
dialogues.text: Haaawooo! The Spartan weapons lower and raise again and again -- each time the men grow louder with their chant of war.

dialogues.speaker: SPARTANS
dialogues.text: Haaawooo! Leonidas nods softly at his men and turns to Daxos.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: You see, old friend? I brought more soldiers than you did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Less  26.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the ground, simple oil-fed cauldrons burn bright, casting shadows that dance along the branches of olive trees. Gorgo meets with a Spartan LOYALIST near the garden's roughly chiseled steps.

dialogues.speaker: LOYALIST
dialogues.text: Is such secrecy needed?

dialogues.speaker: GORGO
dialogues.text: When is one to trust beyond the walls of their own home? Even here, Theron has eyes and ears that fuel Sparta with doubt and fear.

dialogues.speaker: LOYALIST
dialogues.text: Don't worry. Leonidas and his men are strong.

dialogues.speaker: GORGO
dialogues.text: It is not his strength that worries me... if Xerxes is not stopped...

dialogues.speaker: LOYALIST
dialogues.text: He will be stopped.

dialogues.speaker: GORGO
dialogues.text: If Persians advance beyond the harrows to the North, they will leave no one to tell our story. They will grind Spartan bones to flour and serve them to their Army. The Loyalist reflects on the Queen's words.

dialogues.speaker: GORGO
dialogues.text: I now bear the weight of the king's responsibility. If Leonidas fights for what he believes, so must I, here in Sparta. Gorgo stands beneath an arbor of lavender.

dialogues.speaker: LOYALIST
dialogues.text: I can arrange for you to speak to the Council. Many would vote to commit all we have and follow Leonidas, but you must show them favor, explain why their King would betray the law of his land. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GORGO
dialogues.text: Laws created by men who have never shown valor.

dialogues.speaker: LOYALIST
dialogues.text: Is it recklessness or valor? Without reason the Council can believe either. Gorgo watches a Spartan guard on horseback ride out of the city into the blackness of night.

dialogues.speaker: GORGO
dialogues.text: I will go to the Council, and if it is reason they want, I will let them know.

dialogues.speaker: LOYALIST
dialogues.text: Know what, my Queen?

dialogues.speaker: GORGO
dialogues.text: How precious this liberty we enjoy is. Why freedom isn't free at all. It comes with the highest of costs. The cost of blood. The Loyalist nods in agreement with his Queen.

dialogues.speaker: LOYALIST
dialogues.text: I'll bring together the city's council, and its chamber will be filled by your voice. The Loyalist gathers himself and readies to leave.

dialogues.speaker: GORGO
dialogues.text: Why do you do this?

dialogues.speaker: LOYALIST
dialogues.text: Leonidas is my King, as well as yours. The Loyalist bows his head and goes without sound, leaving the Queen to view the stars that spread across the obsidian night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Most Spartans sleep, huddled near each other, laying over their bronze shields like massive rag dolls of war. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The Captain moves across the campsite to Leonidas. They watch the bursts of dying sparks jump out of the flames and vanish.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: No sleep tonight?

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: Not for the King. Leonidas studies the fire.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: Too restless... eager as a youth... eager as a beardless wet- nosed cadet for battle. Leonidas looks towards his men and then back to the Captain. They share a moment and nod, a moment only shared and understood by men who have given themselves fully to one thing their whole lives. Leonidas" voice quiets.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: All my forty years have been a straight road to this one gleaming moment in destiny. This one radiant clash of shield and spear and sword and bone and flesh and blood. Leonidas returns to the fire, watching it dance. The King's eyes close for a moment. Just a dream of sleep would be enough.

dialogues.speaker: EXT, PINDOS MOUNTAINS
dialogues.text: The day has turned and grey mist rises in ghostly shapes from the spine of the mountains. The band of brothers descends through the merciless heat. Astinos points to the ridgeline.

dialogues.speaker: ASTINOS
dialogues.text: We are being followed. The silhouetted figure looms, watching the Spartans' progress.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: It has followed us since Sparta.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: A Persian scout? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The Spartans rest for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: No. Its stride is more beast than man. Stelios points to thin columns of black smoke on the blue horizon.

dialogues.speaker: STELIOS
dialogues.text: Look, my King.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the Spartans and Greeks enter. Buildings still smolder and fall to ash. A complete wasteland, void of hope and song, filled with smell of slaughtered livestock and the dead.

dialogues.speaker: STELIOS
dialogues.text: What happened here? Where are the people? Leonidas scans the details of the destruction. Footprints in the wet earth, hooves of strange beasts, torn bits of a peasant's dress. Leonidas crouches, tracing with his finger the claw-like footprints in the blood-soaked earth.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: Persians. The Captain kneels next to Leonidas after surveying the scene.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: I put their numbers at around twenty.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: A scouting party... But these footprints... What could have...

dialogues.speaker: STELIOS
dialogues.text: A child! The Spartans turn to see the naked form of a CHILD. A phantom, her thin pale body, covered in dirt and dried blood. The mass of Greek warriors part as she moves between them and stands before Leonidas in silence.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: Water. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CHILD
dialogues.text: It's quiet now... They... they came with beasts from the blackness... monsters... dark- skinned... cold eyes... from my nightmares. The Child is stoic in her telling of the tale.

dialogues.speaker: CHILD
dialogues.text: With their claws and fangs they grabbed them... everyone... everyone but me.

dialogues.speaker: SPARTAN
dialogues.text: I've found them. A Spartan points to a massive wind-blown tree at the top of a hill. The Child collapses at the feet of the King. Leonidas slowly lifts her into his arms. He closes the eyes of the lifeless child and looks towards the lone ancient tree. Where VILLAGERS, MAN, WOMAN, CHILD have been strung out like Christmas ornaments, hundreds of Persian arrows pierced through their limbs and bodies.

dialogues.speaker: STELIOS
dialogues.text: Have the gods no mercy!

dialogues.speaker: DAXOS
dialogues.text: We are doomed

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: Quiet yourself. The Spartans and free Greeks move slowly towards the haunting tree. Leonidas stands without expression, holding the dead child.

dialogues.speaker: DAXOS
dialogues.text: The child speaks of the Persian ghosts, knows from the ancient times, bound by the myth and magic of the night... They are the hunters of men's souls. Some of the Greeks nervously look at each other. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oe

dialogues.speaker: DAXOS
dialogues.text: They cannot be killed or defeated, not this darkness, not these immortals. Leonidas lays the small child's frame at the base of the tree.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: Immortals? We will put their name to the test.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leonidas pauses, watching the men stream down past him into the narrow canyon called the Hot Gate. The WIND HOWLS through the ancient cut in the mountains and the crimson Spartan capes... ... SNAP like flags.

dialogues.speaker: DILIOS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: We march... from Lakonia... from sacred Sparta... we march... for Honor's sake... for Glory's sake... we march... Into hell's mouth.we march. Leonidas nods to a few passing brothers, dust swirls as the Captain and his son pass. Leonidas and the Captain share a moment which causes the Captain to slap a strong hand on his son's back, smile at him, a father and son joined in battle, and then turns back to Leonidas. The look of pride still on his face. The Captain makes his way through the current of soldiers to stand next to his King, his friend. As the troops thunder past, the two survey the landscape for a moment, looking down through the Hot Gates to the ocean. Dilios stops and points into the far distance.

dialogues.speaker: DILIOS
dialogues.text: Look! Persians! Countless Persian ships bob like toys on an angry sea, pulling down distant sails in preparation for a coming storm. Black bellies of clouds mix with the last light of day. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DILIOS
dialogues.text: Did you know the God King Xerxes requires no less than 8,000 slaves to move and assemble his personal compound. That the zoo of animals that accompany him consume over 100 tons of wheat, hay and meat a day. That their Persian war brothel is contained in over 80 tents and its number of concubines, goats and war boys outnumber us 3 to 1. And that the column of carts that bear the skins and barrels of fermented barley and wine is over 15 miles long.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: Well, at least we'll die with the stench of Persian whores on our cocks and the taste of Persian wine on our lips.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: Die perhaps... or live forever.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: An optimist.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: I can afford to be... I've got you on my side. The Captain nods to his friend as the nearing soldiers clamor by...

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: You do indeed. The burden of Kingship you bear alone, but our friendship we bear together. Dilios takes a few steps past Leonidas, following the men who head down to the sea, then turns back to them.

dialogues.speaker: DILIOS
dialogues.text: Come, let's watch these motherless dogs as they are embraced by the loving arms of Greece herself. Leonidas takes a look at the sky and then back to the Persian fleet.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: True, it does look like rain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lightning flashes across a violent sky, exploding the mast of a Persian trireme. The vessel is tossed on giant SURF, CRASHING it into the rocky coast.

dialogues.speaker: DILIOS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Let the others scurry for cover. : We rush to bear witness. The Gods play. Zeus stabs the sky with thunderbolts. Boreas howls, bullied... and batters the sea with hurricane wind. Daxos joins Leonidas and his men as they stand above the sea on the cliff watching as one after another, the Persian fleet is smashed in SLOW MOTION, to kindling. Below, another bolt of lightning briefly illuminates faces of the countless drowning slave oarsmen gasping for breath among the splintered timbers of the Persian Armada.

dialogues.speaker: DILIOS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Poseidon rises, rudely awakened, furious, his surf clawing at the stars. The RAIN POUNDS against Leonidas' shield like war drums as he drinks in the carnage below.

dialogues.speaker: DILIOS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Glorious. Behind Leonidas, his men laugh. Cries of jubilation are heard. The men embrace and Daxos raises his fist in * victory as another massive Persian ship explodes onto the rocks and again the surf surges made viscous by flesh and wood.

dialogues.speaker: DILIOS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Laughter, song and praise for the Gods that will continue to the next day's dawn. Then another flash of lightning as the men behind him dance with time suspended, in ecstasy of jubilation. Leonidas, jaw set, face cold, stern and motionless, says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: DILIOS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Only one among us keeps his Spartan reserve. Leonidas slowly lowers his shield, allowing the rain to run down his unmoving face. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: DILIOS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Only he. THUNDER mixed with laughter and the pounding sea. The distant cries of a host of drowning Persians. Leonidas lifts his chin in slow motion to the rain and closes his eyes, breathes the salty air and turns back through his men to the Spartan camp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: t Only our King.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: | A handful of Spartans moves silently through the misty forest at a pace impossibly fast for the lack of sound. No helmets, no shields. g FLASHES of red and steel between the trunks of mountain pines.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Spartan points to the edge of a bluff just in front of them, the forest silhouetted by the bright sky, telling * Daxos they have reached the overlook they had ventured i into the woods to find. He crawls on his belly until he is next to the Spartans who lie at the cliff's edge looking down on the Persian encampment. Daxos' breath catches in his throat as terror grips him staring down on the camp of his enemy. WE SEE: the greatest gathering of men and animals the world has ever seen, for the valley below him, which stretches five miles across, bordered on one side by the | sea and on the other by the mountains, contains from ed j to edge a city of tents complete with roads that team with people and carts and horse and creatures no Greek eye has seen before. At the coast, countless thousands of ships are being unloaded and tended to. Vast legions of men march this way and that, the smoke from the tens of thousands of fires has created a cloud of black that drifts and clings over the nearby mountains.

dialogues.speaker: DAXOS
dialogues.text: I saw those ships smashed on the rocks. How can this be?

dialogues.speaker: SPARTAN
dialogues.text: We saw but a fraction of the monster that is Xerxes' army. The Spartan smiles, shaking his head at the sheer spectacle. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DAXOS
dialogues.text: We are doomed. There can be no victory here. Why do you smile?

dialogues.speaker: SPARTAN
dialogues.text: Arcadian, I have fought countless times... Yet I have never met an adversary who could offer me what we Spartans call a Beautiful Death. I can only hope with all the world's warriors gathered against us that there might be one down there who's up to the task. With that he slaps a hand on Daxos' back and laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WE SEE: a form, half-man/half-unknown, who has followed Leonidas. Its hunched back, gruesome and abstract, face rutted and worn like leather. EPHIALTES moves with a broken gait, mouth shaped like a gunshot wound, eyes uneven, wild with determination.

dialogues.speaker: EPHIALTES
dialogues.text: Honored father... Smile down upon me from your place of rest. This day your son will prove himself. Ephialtes' feet trample over the wild scrub and withered flowers sheathed in dust.

dialogues.speaker: EPHIALTES
dialogues.text: I will show you that you were not wrong to protect me. I will show | you that I am worthy. Ephialtes stops at the edge of a high cliff, cupping his misshapen hand towards his face, inhaling deeply, smelling, questioning the air itself.

dialogues.speaker: EPHIALTES
dialogues.text: Bastards. WE HEAR: the sound of TROOPS marching in the distance. A PERSIAN GENERAL carried atop a golden throne, surrounded by BODYGUARDS. He whips his slaves and pushes them on.

dialogues.speaker: EPHIALTES
dialogues.text: Persian bastards! We'll kill all of you. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Ephialtes grits his teeth and growls at the passing Persian display.

dialogues.speaker: EPHIALTES
dialogues.text: We Spartans will destroy you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morning calisthenics. Leonidas leans on his spear, i watching. A summer WIND blows cool off the Aegean. * Bodies straight, teeth clenched at the zenith of a * military push up, they hold that pose. On each of their backs stands another Spartan with shield, helmet, spear and cape. Muscles shake and quiver under 200 pounds of men and armor. i Daxos rushes into the Spartan campsite. Leonidas turns | from his men who can be heard in the b.g.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leonidas is calm, almost pleasant.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: Daxos, you're up early for an Arcadian. Daxos is scared, he points in the direction of the sea.

dialogues.speaker: DAXOS
dialogues.text: } A Persian General approaches. You | should come and speak to him. It : is our one chance for survival. The King nods slowly at Daxos. *

dialogues.speaker: DAXOS
dialogues.text: You are the King. Your men are * t ill-prepared for the delicate { matters of state. I1 fear the | welcome that this ambassador will receive and the message it sends to Xerxes. Leonidas smiles at Daxos.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: No, on second thought, I am busy. My boys will meet him at the wall ' and I think you will find them quite prepared to show him a proper Spartan welcome.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Persians advance up the primitive highway. The Persian General's gold litter, carried by twelve slaves at a dead run, suddenly slows as it approaches the Hot Gates. Fear grips the dark-skinned slaves who carry the General. More afraid of what they see than the General's whip.

dialogues.speaker: DILIOS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Perhaps King Xerxes sent his General to negotiate our surrender. Or perhaps he wonders why he has not heard from his scouts. As they round the last bend, the Hot Gates still in the distance, they are greeted by two dozen dead Persian scouts. Each impaled by a spear so that it protrudes from his mouth. The shafts of the spears inside their bodies cause them to sit upright. The dead scouts adorn the rocks and dirt mounds, a signpost to the General that he is headed in the right direction. His handful of bodyguards are frozen as they stare at the gruesome display.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ephialtes watches the Persian General and his column of men fade into the distance.

dialogues.speaker: EPHIALTES
dialogues.text: Destroy them, right up their camel-callused backsides. Ephialtes spins and thrusts the sky with his. spear in mock battle.

dialogues.speaker: EPHIALTES
dialogues.text: Blessed Spartans! The boldest of men. The finest warriors in all the world! He turns and opens his stride across the sharp rocks.

dialogues.speaker: EPHIALTES
dialogues.text: They will accept me. They must accept me. Father! Beloved Mother! You will see that you were right to protect me. And now the creature runs. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The path is strange and solemn. Among the ferns and mountain oaks, granite shelves, ragged escarpments of stone and earth braced by the invisible hands of the Gods themselves. He runs to warn his Spartans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Near the entrance to the Hot Gates. The Persian General half-stands out of the ornate chair, borne on the shoulders of bleeding slaves, to better see who among his enemies are gathered at the wall which now acts as a barrier, funneling would-be attackers into the Hot Gates. A large group of Spartans work at putting the finishing touches to the wall. Stelios puts a large rock in place at the top of the wall and, already sweating hard, glances at the approaching General who calls up to him.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL
dialogues.text: You there! Who commands here? Stelios stares down at him, then to the water below. He takes a breath and leaps fifty feet to the sea. His form is perfect. The General watches as he hits the water headfirst with barely a splash. The General looks at the men as they work on the wall. No one has stopped. The General stands, frustrated, on the platform supported by slaves, and calls again to the men working on the wall.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL
dialogues.text: IT am the emissary of the Ruler of all the World, the God of Gods, the King of Kings and I demand by that authority that you show me your commander. One or two of the Arcadians look over their shoulders at the Persian General.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL
dialogues.text: Listen and learn, Spartans. I am tired of your petulance. Stelios climbs the cliff face up out of the salt water. He leans against a boulder and begins sharpening his sword with a found stone. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL
dialogues.text: Do you think that the paltry dozen you slew scares us or means anything to us? They are nothing to the great Xerxes. Why, these hills swarm with our scouts. They watch us even now. They move like shadows. The men still work, moving the rocks, handing them to one another, ignoring the Persian General, who laughs a one- breath laugh and looks to his nervous men. He then points at the wall.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL
dialogues.text: Do you think your pathetic wall will do anything except fall like a heap of dry leaves in the face of... His words catch in his throat as he sees that the wall before them is built not just out of stone. WE SEE: Jammed between the boulders and rocks are the heads, limbs, and bodies of countless Persian scouts. Even their horses have not been spared. Their faces in grim crimson and black clotted blood against the gray of stones. The General and his horrified bodyguards scan the wall which looms before them. A monument to death. Stelios lowers his chin, glides his sharpening stone one last time down the length of his BLADE which -- RINGS with sparks and the song of iron on stone. The General struggles for something to say.

dialogues.speaker: STELIOS
dialogues.text: Our ancestors built this wall using ancient stones from the bosom of Greece herself and, with a little Spartan help, you Persians supplied the mortar.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL
dialogues.text: You will pay for your barbarism. And with that, he loads his whip to strike. Stelios, without hesitation, closes the distance to the General in a heartbeat. Rising in a powerful leap, his freshly sharpened sword FLASHES through the General's arm at the elbow. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The General's litter crashes to the ground. His slaves dive for the protection of nearby rocks. Stelios stands over the General as he grips his stump in pain, blood pumping between his fingers. Each of his bodyguards frozen at spear point by the now agitated Spartans.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL
dialogues.text: My arn!

dialogues.speaker: STELIOS
dialogues.text: It's not yours anymore. Go now. Run along and tell your Xerxes he faces free men here. Not Slaves. Do it quickly before we decide to make this wall just a littie bit bigger. The General breathes a labored breath, swallows hard and narrows his brow.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL
dialogues.text: Not slaves, no. Your women will be slaves, though. Your sons and daughters, and elders will be slaves. But not you. By noon this day you will be dead men. Stelios is unmoved by the General's speech.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL
dialogues.text: One hundred nations of the Persian Empire descend upon you. The General is helped back to his golden perch and his slaves shoulder his lighter weight. He turns one last time, to the massive wall, to the men that built it, and the butcher that took his arm.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL
dialogues.text: Our arrows will blot out the sun. Stelios never changes his expression. His eyes are as cold as the bracing AEGEAN which CRASHES relentlessly on the cliffs below.

dialogues.speaker: STELIOS
dialogues.text: Then we will fight in the shade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leonidas and his Captain watch as the Persian Ambassador retreats back to Xerxes and his legions. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: The wall is solid. It will do the job of channeling the Persians into the Hot Gates, and the rest of our defenses are nearly complete.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: Captain, have the men found any route through the hills to our back?

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: None, sir. Atop the brown stones and pale ground stands Ephialtes, like a broken creature.

dialogues.speaker: EPHIALTES
dialogues.text: There is such a route, good King. Ephialtes lowers his bronze shield to reveal his entire body.

dialogues.speaker: EPHIALTES
dialogues.text: Just past that western ridge. It's an old goat path. The Persians could use it to outflank us. The Captain steps forward and levels his spear at Ephialtes' frame.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: Not one step closer, Monster. Ephialtes bows his head towards Leonidas.

dialogues.speaker: EPHIALTES
dialogues.text: Wise King, I humbly request an audience. The Captain stands firm.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: I'll skewer you where you stand! Leonidas lowers his spear in front of the Captain's chest, stopping him from advancing towards Ephialtes.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: I gave no such order. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The Captain looks to his King and backs away slowly, watching Ephialtes as he returns to his men who prepare for the Persians.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: Forgive the Captain. He is a good soldier... but a bit short on manners, Ephialtes squints and shortens his gaze to Leonidas.

dialogues.speaker: EPHIALTES
dialogues.text: There is nothing to forgive, brave King. I know what I look like.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: You wear the crimson of a Spartan. Ephiaites steps closer to the King, lifting his head with pride.

dialogues.speaker: EPHIALTES
dialogues.text: I am Ephialtes, born of Sparta. My mother's love led my parents to flee Sparta, lest I be discarded. [ My father became a shepherd... but he taught me the warrior's way.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: Your weapons and armor?

dialogues.speaker: EPHIALTES
dialogues.text: My father's, sir. | Silence lays between the King and the eager soul.

dialogues.speaker: EPHIALTES
dialogues.text: I beg you, bold King, to permit me to redeem my father's name by serving you... in combat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: i Leonidas leans onto a smooth, cool stone.

dialogues.speaker: EPHIALTES
dialogues.text: You will see... Day and night my father trained me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: i i Ephiaites opens his stance and twirls the shaft of his spear, blurring the speed of its arc. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: EPHIALTES
dialogues.text: To feel no fear... to show no pain... to make spear and shield and sword as much a part of me as my own beating heart. Ephialtes jabs his spear towards the Persian camps in the distance, breathing, growling at the imaginary men that fall before him.

dialogues.speaker: EPHIALTES
dialogues.text: You see? My arms are strong and my reach is long. I will earn my father's armor, noble King... and reclaim my family's honor.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: A fine thrust...

dialogues.speaker: EPHIALTES
dialogues.text: I will kill many Persians! Leonidas stands, shadow towering over the warped form of Ephialtes.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: Raise your shield! Ephialtes stops his attack.

dialogues.speaker: EPHIALTES
dialogues.text: Sir?

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: Raise your shield as high as you can. Ephialtes lifts the shield. He is half hidden behind the circle of hammered bronze.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: Your father should have taught you how our Phalanx works. We fight as a single impenetrable unit. That is the source of our strength. Leonidas demonstrates the defensive stance.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: Each Spartan protects the man to his left from thigh to neck with his shield. A single weak spot... and the phalanx shatters. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Leonidas takes his hand to the top of Ephialtes' shield and measures the height, a good two feet shy of the needed mark.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: From thigh to neck, Ephialtes. The King shakes his head slowly as Ephialtes lowers his shield.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: I am sorry, my friend, not all of us are made to be soldiers.

dialogues.speaker: EPHIALTES
dialogues.text: But I... Leonidas places his hand on the shoulder of Ephialtes.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: If you want to help Sparta in its victory, you can clear the battlefield of the dead, tend the wounded, bring them water, but as for the fight itself, I cannot use you. The King turns quietly away and heads down the slope of limestone towards his 300.

dialogues.speaker: EPHIALTES
dialogues.text: Mother, Father, you were wrong. Ephialtes turns away, towards the cliff's edge.

dialogues.speaker: EPHIALTES
dialogues.text: You are wrong, Leonidas. You are wrong! But the King continues, growing smaller in the distance. Ephialtes turns and leaps from the cliff, disappearing from the high outcropping of rock, making not another sound. The Captain watches as Leonidas crosses the folds of rock, windblown brush, shade-dappled grass, fine as thread.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: (to the Captain) Dispatch the Phocians to the goat path and pray to the Gods that nobody tells the Persians about it. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The Earth begins to shake and lift, rocks loosen and cascade down the cliff face. The Spartans and the other Greeks steady themselves. The distant RUMBLING GROWS... STRONGER... LOUDER!

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: Battle formations! Without hesitation the Spartan guard and others move quickly, grabbing their weapons.

dialogues.speaker: DILIOS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: For a beast approaches... savoring the meal to come.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And from the very sea itself, the Persian tents and rally-points empty and break ground. They charge upwards through the valley. They come in hordes, forward, fast, over the rocks and shallows, they race on.

dialogues.speaker: DILIOS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: A force of men so massive it shakes the earth with its march. Brown bearded forms, chest panels of crocodile cover ragged men, smoothed leather head covers adorned with seashells and human bones.

dialogues.speaker: DILIOS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: An Army so vast... beyond imagining. The Persians flow upward, through the valley floor and foothills of the mountains.

dialogues.speaker: DILIOS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Poised to devour tiny Greece. Like locusts the Persians swarm over the land, destroying beneath their advance all that holds life. Nothing is spared.

dialogues.speaker: DILIOS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: To snuff out the world's one hope for reason and justice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Armor is lifted. Leonidas runs forward, leading from the front. The Captain and his 300 follow him down the broken path.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: Follow your King. Stelios lets out a battle cry that ECHOES off the steep rock faces on either side of him. Dilios and the Captain's son join him as they drop down along the funnel of stone.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: Earn your shields, boys. They fork around obstacles, flow down en masse toward the Hot Gates. Over rocks they leap. Today there is no need to hunt... the Spartan prey is before them... one million of them!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WE HEAR: The sounds of HOOVES and HORSES, like distant thunder, GROWING CLOSER! Blue-turbaned riders, atop sleek Arabian horses, dozens break the low hills and funnel past the wall of the dead. Now, hundreds of horses are in full gallop over the high grass. Riders lean forward on their mounts, eyes fierce, scanning for Greek blood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leonidas settles himself as the rest of his men arrive. They form quickly around their King, quieting their racing hearts, and listen to his words over the Persian. juggernaut.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: This is where we hold them! The Spartans watch as the earth moves and undulates, heaves forward, alive with forms dressed in loose silk and cloth. They carry curved swords, ivory-handled daggers tucked into belts of gold. Horsemen whip the infantry forward, while others reach into wicker quivers that hold arrows from the East.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: This is where we fight! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The Spartans lower their shields into a perfect phalanx, a solid wall of bronze from one side of the Hot Gates to the other. Each man protects the next, each with spear extended towards the Persian wave.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: This is where they die! The Persian funnel off the Wall of the Dead up the last steps of the Hot Gates.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: Remember this day, men, for it will be yours for all time. A snow-white Arabian and RIDER slows... the mass of Xerxes' machine of war slows... as the golden shields of Leonidas and his Spartans are revealed.

dialogues.speaker: PERSIAN HORSEMAN
dialogues.text: Spartans! The air is heavy with the smells of leather, iron and sweat. Leonidas and his 300 do not move, only their breath can be heard against each other's backs.

dialogues.speaker: PERSIAN HORSEMAN
dialogues.text: Lay down your weapons! WE SEE: From the Wall of the Dead appears the slow arc of a single javelin through the air. It settles quickly into the chest of the Persian Horseman, toppling him from his mount, dead before he touches Greek soil. Leonidas narrows his eyes to his enemies.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: Persians... Come and get them! And with the defiance of the Gods themselves, Leonidas starts what many speak of but few have the heart for.

dialogues.speaker: WAR BEGINS
dialogues.text: WE HEAR: First faint, then rising with the ranks, a low RUMBLING. Strange HORNS and CALLS TO WAR lift from the Persians, as if to warn of the Apocalypse that will follow.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: Shoulder to shoulder. The Spartan phalanx snaps to a perfect oak and bronze wall of defense. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Beneath the hammered bronze, eyes locked forward, towards the howling enemy. The front rows of the Phalanx lower their lances of cornel wood and ash, eight feet from hand to razor-tipped end. This stand of men appears unworldly, as if some breathing metal beast that lays coiled, ready to attack. The force of Persian RAIDERS drops down the last open space and funnels straight to Leonidas and his men.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: Hold. The Spartans brace for battle.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: Give them nothing. Assyrians, Arabians, Bactrians, Cappadocians, Medes, Karians, Babylonians, Armenians, and other Asiatic tribes, a hundred nations thunder forward at the Spartan line.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: But take from them, everything. The Persians close within twenty yards of the forest of Spartan arms.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: Steady, boys. CRASH! East meets West. Wicker meets bronze. The Spartan line grits its teeth against the massive Persian onslaught. Thousands of Persians push against the wall of Spartan bronze. Sandals slide, plowing the earth as Spartan feet are forced back. A Persian blade draws the first Spartan blood, grazing across the shoulder of a young Spartan. He cries out in anger, breathing hate into the Spartan will. Leonidas strains as he and his men finally slow the tide of silk and wicker, steel and dark skin. They find a foothold that stops their backwards movement, and all at once a thousand Persian eyes grow large with fear as Leonidas lowers his body, pushes forward, thrusting through Persians two at a time. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The Captain rolls over the enemy without pause. Piercing through the silk leggings, puncturing their lungs with such power that the air escapes the chest wounds in great geysers.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: Push on!!! They push on, never breaking their impenetrable human wall.

dialogues.speaker: DILIOS
dialogues.text: Aaaahhhh! Dilios' jabs land, cutting into Persian throats, the cries of pain muffled as they fall under the trampling feet of Spartan advance.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: Push!!!! They push on... The Spartans gather strength from Greece herself, the invaders fall upon each other, one after the other. WE HEAR: The CRIES of men, strange tongues from foreign lands, GROANS and SCREAMS drift out and fall back to the lifeless bodies from which they came.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: Clear... to the right. Scared Persians, hearts pounding in hollow determination, fall quick prey to the skill of the Spartans.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: No prisoners!

dialogues.speaker: SPARTANS
dialogues.text: Haaawooo!!! They step and thrust, killing all before them.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: No mercy!

dialogues.speaker: SPARTANS
dialogues.text: Haaawooo!!!! A deafening advance, the Spartans repel the Persian discharge with ease, forcing the incalculable numbers backwards. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: They look thirsty.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: Give them something to drink, boys.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: To the cliffs! The Spartan phalanx jolts too. Electrified, they push their burnished defense, relentless, driving over Persian bodies, grinding towards the coastal cliffs. Leonidas lurches, skewering another. The rear columns of attacking Persians begin to fold and fall away, over the high cliff's edge and into the sea below. WE HEAR: Gasps of men without earth beneath then, falling forms. High-pitched wails and caterwauls bleed forth and crumple back onto the force as they are pushed over the rocky line. By the hundreds they fall, embroidered tunics and mail jackets tumble, continuous and measured screams sing out as the Persians distort and separate into the churning salty grave.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: Hold. With the King's voice, the Spartans stop and watch the last Persian sail over the cliff face and disappear without a sound,

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: Hell of a good start.

dialogues.speaker: SPARTANS
dialogues.text: Haawooo! WE HEAR: Distant Arabian HORNS sound off. As a thousand HARPIES SCREECH and arrows cut loose.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: Tuck tail! The Spartans drop to a knee and cover their bodies with the bronze shelter from the incoming storm. The first wave of bronze heads sink into the ground around Leonidas and his men. Shaft after shaft rains into the Spartan shields, momentarily obscuring the sun with their volume. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: Persian cowards. Bowmen reach into their quivers and send more missiles by the thousands, an attack of size and strength never seen by Leonidas and his men. Astinos crouches, laughing beneath his makeshift bronze roof.

dialogues.speaker: STELIOS
dialogues.text: What in the hell are you laughing at?

dialogues.speaker: ASTINOS
dialogues.text: You had to say it. Arrows pound off their shields, deflect, SHAFTS SNAP, they fall in a deluge, pinning Astinos' robe to the ground.

dialogues.speaker: STELIOS
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: ASTINOS
dialogues.text: Fight in the shade. They both begin to laugh and now the others join in. As the last shrieking volley is cut loose... All is silent, save the Spartans laughter on the battlefield.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: Settle down. Leonidas looks to his Captain.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: Let them laugh. It scares the fight out of our enemy. The Captain nods.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: Recover. A cry erupts from the back of the Spartan formation. In the front position, Leonidas sees the mass of beast and men they now offer. His eyes widen to the sheer force and he sets his body for the impact.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: No heroes... Today no Spartan dies! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Astinos looks to his Father. The Captain nods softly, a simple gesture of recognition that comforts his son before Hell arrives. Nostrils flare as the giant sand-colored beasts thunder down upon the Spartan line. The Captain locks his shield into his body. Stelios fights back fear, his breath quickening in time with the advancing mounts. An explosion of pure violence. Persians are thrown from their strange mounts, bodies trampled; sweat and blood runs freely. Terror carved and molded to each Persian face. ee

dialogues.speaker: DILIOS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: We do what we were trained to do!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Spartans advance with tremendous velocity, half-naked forms, red ribbons, brilliant bronze armor rushing forward without pause.

dialogues.speaker: DILIOS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: What we were bred to do! The Persians fight with curved swords, small war axes and hammers engraved with lions' heads.

dialogues.speaker: DILIOS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: What we were born to do! It is as abstract as it is brutal. Persian men, torn limbs, unclothed bodies, crushed and bloody, wounded figures, empty hand-tooled saddles, beheaded camels, faceless masses clutching to breath and pulse, one by one falling again and again to Spartan endurance.

dialogues.speaker: DILIOS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: No prisoners! No mercy! A good start.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WE SEE: Gorgo and her son moving through the crowded marketplace. Pleistarchos playfully darts between stone columns and pools of bright sunlight. The two move in a loose pair past dark chambers, where

dialogues.speaker: BLACKSMITHS --
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: t

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: -- POUND bronze and iron into blade and bowl. Potters shape red clay in vessels and plate. Gorgo stops at the mouth of an alley and calls to her son, who has disappeared behind a gaggle of HOUSEMAIDS, who bicker and gossip.

dialogues.speaker: GORGO
dialogues.text: I am not chasing after you. The Queen waits a moment and sighs.

dialogues.speaker: GORGO
dialogues.text: That's it, I'm leaving. Do you hear me? Gorgo turns down the alley shaking her head. She passes the red homespun fabric, freshly dyed, they hang drying in the midday sun. The shadows of the hanger bars flash across her face as she moves between the blood-red fabric walls into a small courtyard. Carved out of stone is a simple bearded face and out of the stone mouth, water flows, falling into a small pool. The Loyalist sits, ringing a rag out in the clear water and places it on his neck.

dialogues.speaker: LOYALIST
dialogues.text: I was afraid you might not come. He stands to his feet as Gorgo approaches.

dialogues.speaker: GORGO
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, my son... is... She turns back towards the alley.

dialogues.speaker: LOYALIST
