dialogues.text: Doing what children do best. Please don't apologize. Gorgo relaxes a bit, made comfortable by the Loyalist's manner.

dialogues.speaker: LOYALIST
dialogues.text: He starts the Agoge next year. That is always a hard time for Spartan mothers.

dialogues.speaker: GORGO
dialogues.text: Yes... it will be hard, but also necessary. The Loyalist ponders with a smile, remembering his time enduring the Spartan crucible. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LOYALIST
dialogues.text: In two days you will speak to the council. Gorgo answers quickly.

dialogues.speaker: GORGO
dialogues.text: My husband does not have two days.

dialogues.speaker: LOYALIST
dialogues.text: Leonidas has chosen his battles and so must you. These two days are a gift. The Queen nods. LOYALIST i It's no secret that Theron wants 3 what you control. It is his voice : you must silence. Make an ally of him and you will have your victory. The moment hangs between them both.

dialogues.speaker: GORGO
dialogues.text: My son will be looking for me. Thank you... You are as wise as you are kind. The Loyalist bows and moves off down a passageway. Gorgo turns to the fountain and splashes water on her face, relief from August heat. She pauses, letting the water pour over her hands, staring into the stone eyes of the fountain. From behind her, a voice.

dialogues.speaker: THERON
dialogues.text: There's your mother. Gorgo turns to find Theron and Pleistarchos. Her son's eyes are nervous as Theron grips his shoulders from behind. Gorgo moves towards them both; Theron lets her son go and he runs to her side.

dialogues.speaker: THERON
dialogues.text: You should keep a better eye on i him if he is to be King one day. i Gorgo pulls her son into her. Theron studies the faces of both Queen and son.

dialogues.speaker: THERON
dialogues.text: It would be unfortunate if anything were to happen to him or his beautiful mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Gorgo narrows her gaze at Theron.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a vision of Hell on Earth. Thousands of Persian dead lay in heaps. The ground turned to mud by the countless gallons of blood. The Spartans work gathering weapons from the fallen and putting the few Persians whose injuries have not killed them, out of their misery. Leonidas and the Captain pull off their helmets. As they do, the Captain sees a Persian crawling among the nearby dead. He moves casually over to him. The Captain looks back toward Leonidas, tossing the King an apple. As Leonidas bites into it, the Captain puts a heavy foot on the Persian to steady him, then plunges a spear through his back. The Persian cries out, then dies. The Captain pulls his spear free and moves to the King.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: The Arcadians are itching for battle, sire. They're begging for a crack at the Persians.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: Good! I've got something I think they can handle. Tell Daxos I want them eager, sober, and ready for the next charge. Stelios runs the last few yards right up to Leonidas .and the Captain.

dialogues.speaker: STELIOS
dialogues.text: (breathing hard) King Leonidas.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: Stelios, catch your breath, boy. Stelios puts his hands on his thighs and drops his head for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: STELIOS
dialogues.text: Yes, My Lord. He breathes deeply, then swallows. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: STELIOS
dialogues.text: Persians approach, My Lord. A small contingent. Too small for an attack. Leonidas looks in the direction of Stelios' spear which he uses as a pointer.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: Captain, you are in charge.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: But, Sire... Leonidas smiles at the Captain.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: Relax, old friend. If they assassinate me, all of Sparta goes to war. Leonidas becomes more serious, his voice lowers.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: Pray they're that stupid... pray we're that lucky. Leonidas begins to move across the landscape of the dead as the Captain sighs, then sees another breathing Persian and raises his spear.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: Besides, there's no reason we can't be civil, is there? The Captain buries his spear with crisp precision and the life groans from one of the nameless horde of his enemy.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: None, sire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A clearing between the Hot Gates and the Persian camps. Leonidas slows to a stop. His expression a subtle smile. A mix of amusement and disbelief at the display before him. For, wedged between the sea and the jagged rock face of the mountains, is a sight as impressive as it is absurd. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 100 men bear on their backs a giant golden throne beset with sculpted lions. Ancient script as old as time itself is carved upon the platform. It rises 20 feet above the shoulders of the bent slaves who carry it. At its summit, surrounded by golden gazelles and backed by a black sun, stands XERXES. Nearly 7 feet tall. Body of lean sinew, hairless, androgynous, and draped in adornments of gold.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: Let me guess. You are Xerxes. Xerxes moves down the richly carpeted stairs of his throne platform to the waiting Leonidas. Xerxes steps down, using the back of a kneeling slave as the final step.

dialogues.speaker: DILIOS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: A voice as smooth as warm oil on well-worn leather and as deep as rolling thunder.

dialogues.speaker: XERXES
dialogues.text: Come, Leonidas. Let us reason together. Xerxes glides on powerful legs as Leonidas stands next to him.

dialogues.speaker: XERXES
dialogues.text: It would be a regrettable waste... it would be nothing short of madness were you, brave king, and your valiant troops to perish all because of a simple misunderstanding.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: Don't lose sleep worrying over us. We're having the time of our lives. Xerxes stops and turns to the Spartan King.

dialogues.speaker: XERXES
dialogues.text: Brave words. Spartan words. I admire you. The strength and honor of your soldiers, their fierce devotion. There is much our cultures could share.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: Haven't you noticed we have been sharing our culture with you all morning? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Xerxes smiles.

dialogues.speaker: KERKES
dialogues.text: Yours is a fascinating tribe. Even now you are defiant, in the face of annihilation and the presence of a god.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leonidas looks up at Xerxes.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: There is a fundamental difference between us. You would kill any of your men to win and I would die for any of mine. As Leonidas and Xerxes stand together, silent archers pull bows taut, keeping an eye on the Spartan King.

dialogues.speaker: KERXES
dialogues.text: You Greeks take pride in your : logic. I suggest you employ it. Consider the beautiful land you so vigorously defend. Picture it reduced to ash at my whim! Leonidas is unmoved.

dialogues.speaker: XERXES
dialogues.text: Consider the fate of your women.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: Clearly you don't know our women. I might as well have marched them up here judging by what I've seen. You have many slaves, Xerxes, but few warriors. It won't be long before they fear my spears more than your whips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leonidas turns away from Xerxes and scans the hillside. Rocks fall in a cascade from a nearby cut in the cliff. Xerxes gently puts his hands on Leonidas’ shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: XERKES
dialogues.text: It is not the lash they fear, it is my divine power. I ama generous God. I can make you rich beyond all measure. Rerxes leans closer to Leonidas, his voice goes to a hush (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: KERXES
dialogues.text: I will make you warlord of all * Greece. You will carry my battle standard into the heart of Europa. Your Athenian rivals will kneel at your feet, if you will but kneel at mine. Leonidas exhales deeply, then steps out from under the & God King's hand and looks at his feet. :

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: You are generous as you are * divine, oh King of Kings. Such an offer only a madman would refuse. The Spartan King then takes a few slow steps away from the towering Xerxes.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: But the idea of kneeling, it's... you see slaughtering all those men of yours has put a nasty cramp in my leg. So kneeling will be hard for me.

dialogues.speaker: XERXES
dialogues.text: You sadden me, Leonidas. For as I am reasonable, so am I vicious, and as I am generous, so am I wrathful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 1 Xerxes' body tenses under the weight of diplomatic word

dialogues.speaker: XERXES
dialogues.text: There will be no glory in your sacrifice. I will erase the memory of Sparta from the histories. Every piece of Greek parchment shall be burned. Every Greek historian and every scribe shall have their eyes put out and their tongues cut from their mouths.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Xerxes is afire, voice raised in contempt for the Spartan King.

dialogues.speaker: XERXES
dialogues.text: Why, uttering the very name of Sparta or Leonidas will be punishable by death. The world will never know you existed at all. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Leonidas turns to Xerxes, eyes as cold as ice.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: The world will know free men stood against a tyrant. That few stood against many, and before this battle was over, that even a God King can bleed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the flat steps, before the Hot Gates. Stelios and Astinos work piling Persian corpses into a great mound at the Wall of the Dead. Muscles strain under the lifeless bodies. The sun has just passed below the mountains, and promise of the night's cold is first spoken by the breeze which rises off the sea.

dialogues.speaker: STELIOS
dialogues.text: You fought well today, for a woman. Stelios tosses the body he's carrying onto the pile.

dialogues.speaker: ASTINOS
dialogues.text: As did you. Maybe if I am injured you will be able to keep up with me. Astinos grunts as he heaves a cool body onto another, as Stelios drags a body by the ankles.

dialogues.speaker: STELIOS
dialogues.text: Maybe I was so far ahead you did not see me. The Captain behind them lifts two bodies over his shoulders and begins to move towards the youths.

dialogues.speaker: ASTINOS
dialogues.text: More likely offering your backside to the Thespians.

dialogues.speaker: STELIOS
dialogues.text: Jealously does not become you, my friend. Stelios throws another on the heaping dead. The two smile at each other. The Captain climbs onto the bodies of his enemies, one Persian over each shoulder, heaving them at Stelios' feet. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Leonidas calls up to them, out of breath, from the foot of the pile.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: Move it, men! Pile those Persians high. ok

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leonidas glances back towards the Persian camp, as a wind of dusk tosses crimson behind him.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: We're in for one wild night!

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The worn road to the Hot Gates. Quiet grips the black cliffs. The sea laps onto ageless rock. A light breeze whispers in the trees and then out of the darkness...

dialogues.speaker: DILIOS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: They have served the dark will of Persian Kings for 500 years. Clouds roll against the quarter moon. Black banners * cover the sky.

dialogues.speaker: DILIOS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Eyes as dark as night. Teeth filed to fangs... soulless. The war DRUMS POUND like the heartbeat of a Titan. A river of black bronze surges toward the Hot Gates.

dialogues.speaker: DILIOS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Wordless, their form. Faultless, moving in such perfect unison. Each collective step strikes the earth like a blow from the Fire God's Hammer. They march! Feet pound the earth. Barely the feet of men, toenail- like claws. WE RISE SLOWLY ALONG the form of black armored skin. Muscular arms protrude from ornate plates inlaid with gold. Maybe ancient writing or design. Only dead men have seen close enough to know. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DILIOS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: The personal guard to King Xerxes himself. The Persian warrior elite. The deadliest fighting force in all Asia. One of the thousands turns TO us, scanning the hillside as his demon brothers pass behind him. A hiss of breath, he bares his saw-blade teeth. His black eyes, shark- like, searching for Spartan blood.

dialogues.speaker: DILIOS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: The Immortals. A nameless Immortal at the front of the column holds up his fist and, as one, they stop. WE HEAR: The DRUMS FLOURISH, then GO SILENT. The Immortal lowers his fist slowly, takes a few tentative steps out of formation and scans the obstacle in his way. A wall of stone and fresh Persian dead, 20 feet high, that runs from cliff wall down to the sea. He stares up at the grotesque sight of his comrades. Something new rises from his belly, freezing his joints, making his breath catch in his throat. Something he has not felt in countless forays on the battlefield -- FEAR!

dialogues.speaker: DILIOS, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: Now, while we are fresh and at our full strength. Before wounds and weariness have taken their toll. The Immortal] at the front reaches with shaking hands to the two sabers slung at his back. Stepping slowly away from the wall, he frees the two long arcing blades and nervously watches the wall for movement.

dialogues.speaker: DILIOS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: The mad King throws the best he has at us. Xerxes has taken the bait. WE MOVE ACROSS the faces of the dead at the top of the wall, until we COME TO REST ON the dull gold of a Spartan helmet, the unblinking eyes of Leonidas is hidden among the dead.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: Spartans, push!!! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: From behind the wall, a hoard of crimson and bronze presses as one against the wall of corpses, which tumbles onto the horrified immortals, breaking like waves onto the first six rows of the Persian elite. WE SEE: Pouring over the mound of dead comes a new swell of Spartan shields and spears, surging down on the stunned Immortals. Leonidas plunges his spear, reaching three deep into the ranks of his enemies. He instantly lands a strong foot into the chest of the skewered man, pushing him with a single powerful stroke of his spear and turns to the next.

dialogues.speaker: DILIOS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Immortals. Well... As our King said, we put their name to the test. With his shield, Stelios blocks a blade strike meant for the Captain who flashes young Stelios a look before ramming his own spear through the attacker's eye socket. This is the hardest fighting they have faced. War cries howl from the Immortals as they battle the Spartans.

dialogues.speaker: TIME SLOWS
dialogues.text: WE SEE: Astinos as he catches an attacking Immortal with his spear, in a single move, draws his sword to dispatch another surging at his side. The blood of his enemies sprays across Leonidas' face as the Spartans push forward into the columns of confused Immortals.

dialogues.speaker: IMMORTAL COMMANDER
dialogues.text: Stand your ground! The COMMANDER is bumped by a retreating soldier. He grabs the fleeing soldier and pushes him back toward the fighting. He yells, spitting his rage.

dialogues.speaker: IMMORTAL COMMANDER
dialogues.text: I said stand your ground!!! Leonidas parries a blow and then drives his spear into another Immortal. One of the Immortals leaps onto the shield of a Spartan attacker. His toes grabbing the bottom of the shield like an ape's hands, pulling the swords at his back free and slicing across the neck of a Spartan soldier, killing him. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The Spartans begin to lose ground to the recovering Immortais. They claw as they rally, their fangs tearing into Spartan flesh. Leonidas fights two at a time, grimacing through clenched teeth. He falls back as the Immortals take their toll on the now withering Spartans, locked in a hand-to-hand struggle with one of the demons. The Immortal's gnashing teeth are just inches from Leonidas’ face. Leonidas is barely able to draw his sword, plunging it into the Immortal's throat. Now from the heart of the Immortal horde, the largest and fiercest of the Immortals rushes forward, a full seven feet tall at the shoulder, veins in his neck bulging like serpents as he roars, collapsing a Spartan shield with a kick while in the same moment decapitating another Spartan not quick enough to retreat behind his shield. : The giant Immortal focuses his milky eyes on Leonidas, who fights and dispatches two of the dark horde. Leonidas locks eyes with the giant, who recognizes the Spartan king and charges toward him. Leonidas quickly recovers a spear and thrusts it at the charging monster, who rises into the air on a thundering stride, cutting clean in two the spear shaft of the king. He lands with his full 370 pounds of crushing muscle on the shield of Leonidas, throwing him back onto the mutilated bodies of the day-old fallen. Leonidas, lying on his back, recovers his wits just long enough to have his sword kicked from his hand. The giant roars again, pulling Leonidas’ helmet off, which spins to rest on the blood-soaked earth. The Immortal pulls his blade down toward the exposed head of the king, who raises his arm, catching the raw metal blade with a roof block on his bronze-covered forearm. Then Leonidas summons from deep within his warrior soul a crushing right to the jaw of the demon, who spits blood as he roars in defiance. The thing tosses his sword down as he moves right into Leonidas' face, roaring as he opens his mouth. A mix of blood and saliva pours in rivulets between the sharpened teeth of the giant while his eyes fix on Leonidas’ neck. The king's muscles strain beneath the mass of the Persian Immortal. In desperation, Leonidas calls...

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: Arcadians... NOW!!! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The giant Immortal is inches from Leonidas' neck when he hears the battle cry of the Arcadians. The monster is momentarily distracted, allowing Leonidas to strain the last remaining inches to reach his sword. He lifts the giant off him on two powerful legs and in the same motion passes his sword between the giant's head and shoulders. The monster's head lands next to the king as his body tumbles to one side. WE SEE: From the small thicket of trees at the center of the Immortals, the earth begins to move. The trees fall, revealing a box canyon filled now with charging Arcadians. Daxos leads his men as they cut into the Immortals. Daxos comes right at the Immortal Commander, who is raising his saber, ready to cut down his own men.

dialogues.speaker: IMMORTAL COMMANDER
dialogues.text: Fight or die where you stand! The eyes of the soldier the Commander threatens go wide, as he sees past his master to the ambushing Greeks descending upon them. The Commander sees his fear and turns just in time for Daxos to plunge his spear through the Commander's neck.

dialogues.speaker: DAXOS
dialogues.text: Go! Show the Spartans what we can do. Daxos pulls the spear free and turns quickly, throwing his spear into an Immortal's chest. Daxos draws his sword, fighting on. Thrusting, jabbing; missing a parry, his arm is cut. In exchange, he plunges his sword into one of the dark horde.

dialogues.speaker: DAXOS
dialogues.text: Call us amateurs, will they? TIME SLOWS. NO SOUND. SAVE THE DRUMS.

dialogues.speaker: DILIOS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: They shout and curse, stabbing wildly, more brawlers than warriors. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: i

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: i

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: WE SEE: Farmer and potter, blacksmith and merchant. Free Greeks all, teeth clenched in a battle rage, thrusting spears and swords through the frightened : throngs of their enemies. Pushing, legs driving shields against piceous bronze. Forcing dozens of heavily- weighted Immortals off the cliffs and into the sea.

dialogues.speaker: DILIOS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: They make a wondrous mess of things. Brave amateurs, they do their part. STILL UNDER THE DRUMS. WE SEE: Leonidas pushing forward, muscles flexing, made hungry by the wide-eyed terror of the Immortals. They fall over each other to flee the attacking Spartan King. As the slaughter continues below, from the cliff overlooking the battlefield, silhouetted by the crescent moon, a dark figure adorned in gold watches as his invincible Immortals fall like wheat under the sickle of the Spartan phalanx.

dialogues.speaker: DILIOS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: ... And a man who fancies himself a God... Kerxes' lips tighten; he breathes deeply through flaring nostrils, as below him even the war drums are silenced.

dialogues.speaker: DILIOS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: .. feels a very human chill crawl up his spine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dozens of Spartan campfires reach into a nigrescent sky. They burn bright, fueled with a kindling of broken Persian arrow shafts by the thousands. Around the fires, warriors mend their wounds with linens and oils of root and herb. They drink of red wine and recount with pride the heroics of the battlefield.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: Our King! WE HEAR a ROAR so primitive it shakes the ground and ECHOES OFF the far canyon walls as the other Spartans sound off. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: t

dialogues.speaker: SPARTANS
dialogues.text: Haaaawoooo!

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: Our honored dead!

dialogues.speaker: SPARTANS
dialogues.text: Haaawooo! Leonidas says nothing, just stares quietly towards the heavens along the far edge of the fire circle and beyond.

dialogues.speaker: DILIOS
dialogues.text: Triumph.

dialogues.speaker: STELIOS
dialogues.text: Yes, the day is ours.

dialogues.speaker: ASTINOS
dialogues.text: And the night too.

dialogues.speaker: DILIOS
dialogues.text: True, for now they fear the night as well. Dilios moves with the shadowed light, in front of his brothers.

dialogues.speaker: DILIOS
dialogues.text: Now, as we rest, the Immortals are crawling back to their master like whipped dogs. The Captain nods slowly and wipes the now cold blood from his hands with a captured turban.

dialogues.speaker: ASTINOS
dialogues.text: Every Persian sees it.

dialogues.speaker: STELIOS
dialogues.text: Whom will Xerxes dare to send next?

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: They will never measure as fine as this. The Captain lifts a red-hot iron rod from the fire's mouth and puts it against a young Spartan's side, burning, smoldering the skin, cauterizing the gaping hole without a sound or expression to fill the night air. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: sears

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: Who among his legions will dare to face us?! The Captain throws the rod back to the fire and again a cheer from the Greek warriors rings into the night.

dialogues.speaker: SPARTANS
dialogues.text: Haaawoooo! Leonidas turns and moves through their war party.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: Children... children! Their King's voice quiets their folly.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: The Medes and Scythians are in open revolt! Xerxes is slaughtering his own troops.

dialogues.speaker: ASTINOS
dialogues.text: There is nothing that can stop us now! Leonidas raises his hand, holding some invisible force that quiets the men.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: Dare we hope... Dare we hope for more than a glorious death? Leonidas lowers his hand and gazes over each of the men's faces, half-filled with firelight.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: Such mad hope... but there it is. Leonidas points out into the darkness of the battlefield.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: Against Asia's endless hordes. Against all odds. The Spartan King returns his eyes to his warriors.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: We can do it! We can hold the Hot Gates! We can win! The Spartans erupt into a chorus of voice.

dialogues.speaker: SPARTANS
dialogues.text: Haawwooo!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the shelf of a near cliff... staring down from the blackness and glow of the moon... Ephialtes tears at the red cape that has hidden his deformed soul.

dialogues.speaker: EPHIALTES
dialogues.text: Gods... I still breathe. I still live. Gods, you are cruel. He rips the cape, it settles near his feet.

dialogues.speaker: EPHIALTES
dialogues.text: Damn you. His crude shape leans over, looking down towards the Spartan campfires, down towards the distant warriors.

dialogues.speaker: EPHIALTES
dialogues.text: Damn you. Damn you, Gods! Damn you, Father... Damn you, Mother... Damn you all to Hell! Ephialtes lifts his father's bronze helmet toward the faultless sky, inspecting the color, its worn strength.

dialogues.speaker: EPHIALTES
dialogues.text: Spartans... Spartans! He throws his helmet to the ground.

dialogues.speaker: EPHIALTES
dialogues.text: The boldest of men! The finest warriors in all the world. Ephialtes grunts in disgust to himself.

dialogues.speaker: EPHIALTES
dialogues.text: Damn you... He turns his broken form and begins into the night, none but himself hearing his voice.

dialogues.speaker: EPHIALTES
dialogues.text: Damn you all!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The second day begins as the first. With full light at their backs, barriers of man and beast pound the earth, into the slaughter they race. Silhouetted forms,

dialogues.speaker: WHIPS CRACK
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Across the backs of a fresh rotation, flooding upwards, across the slain and haunted bodies. The men pull from their guts a low growling HOWL!

dialogues.speaker: DILIOS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: One hundred nations descend upon us. The Armies of all Asia. Funneled into this narrow corridor, their numbers count for nothing. They claw and dig into the muddy ground, barreling towards the Hot Gates and the awaiting Spartan line.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: Back to hell with you. Blood and terror pounding at the temples of the oncoming pack of Xerxes' front men.

dialogues.speaker: DILIOS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: The raiding party arrives, unfortunate for being the first to meet the Spartan Nation.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: Attack, now! They collide with such force into the bronze shields, shudder cycling through SNAPPING! Fresh bones. Others push from behind, but nothing is gained as Leonidas plows his pike through the chest of one and moves quickly at silencing another. Armless PERSIAN GIANTS run with wicker baskets on their backs. Within the baskets, MIDGET ARCHERS cut loose a volley a projectiles.

dialogues.speaker: DILIOS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: At our wall of bronze and crimson, there is no retreat, there is no surrender. Only honor... duty... glory... combat... victory. They fall by the hundreds... We send the severed bodies and fragile hearts back to Xerxes' feet. Stelios rams against the hordes, cutting through thin tissue and capillaries, lashing out, moving in pace with his brothers on the steep slope. Tribesmen, tattoos covering their bodies, sling broken shards of glass and porcupine quills into the fight. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Astinos drops his lance into a Persian thigh and strokes upwards, through the groin and out the chest cavity.

dialogues.speaker: DILIOS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: When muscle failed they turned to their magic. But we were relentless... unstoppable... We were free men... We are Spartans. PERSIAN WIZARDS, draped in black velvet robes, throw clay pots mixed of sulfur, bat dung and ash. Its noxious smoke rising, obscuring the fight. - Dilios nails two charging infantrymen with the tip of h spear. Robbing them of any glory, any hope of tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In front of Xerxes' myriad tents, a long line of his Generals wait.

dialogues.speaker: DILIOS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: King Xerxes is displeased with his generals. Xerxes' eyes blaze. Veins bulge in his forehead and neck; he grits his teeth. His rage spitting from his mouth, he commands the executioner, whose form is grotesquely muscled. Where his forearms should be, his flesh and hands have been removed. His very bones sharpened into twin executioner's axes. WE SEE: His arms fall!

dialogues.speaker: DILIOS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: He disciplines them. And with time still suspended, one of his many disappointing Generals is parted from his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WE HEAR: The TRUMPETING of not brass horn but angry and wild BEASTS.

dialogues.speaker: DILIOS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Xerxes dispatches his monsters from half the world away. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: WE SEE: Around the bend. A cavalry of elephants en mass. Elephants adorned with spikes and cleated shoes, stomp through their own men. Their trunks fitted with hammers and bladed sickles. They swing, clearing a path to the Spartans.

dialogues.speaker: THUNDERING
dialogues.text: Up the constricted path, on the gray massive backs, Xerxes' men, 10 deep, archers, javelin throwers, young boys throwing stones down into the battle.

dialogues.speaker: DILIOS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: They are clumsy beasts and the piled Persian dead are slippery. The elephants lose footing, some topple, others shift in fear. A Persian meets his fate, skewered through a charging tusk. Others are tossed like a desultory of tribesman, off the beast and disappear under the charge of nations.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: Break... Now! And with the coming magnitude of Persians, the Spartans open the phalanx and swallow the enemy whole. Leonidas is in perfect form, cutting the enemy down, each stroke and parry, a grace for others to emulate. His shield takes a crushing blow from a Persian battleaxe. He counters and yaws forward, surrendering his spear tip into the face of a Persian Commander, snapping it clean, he draws his sword.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: Watch them! In front, Stelios and Astinos break free, filled by youth. They cleave their swords into an open space of Persian dead. Stelios buries his blade, the Persian falling at his feet.

dialogues.speaker: ASTINOS
dialogues.text: Are you still here? Stelios pulls at his steel, stuck in the corpse he just felled.

dialogues.speaker: STELIOS
dialogues.text: If only you fought as much as you ran your mouth. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Astinos laughs and swings through a string of Persians that streams toward Stelios, still trying to free his blade.

dialogues.speaker: ASTINOS
dialogues.text: Not now, I am a little busy. Astinos is dynamic, effortless, and brave as he takes on three Persian guardsmen. He cuts and pulls at them, dropping the first. Stelios frees his sword, tearing it loose and reenters the fight. Astinos drops the second and turns to Stelios. They continue on, all of the Spartans, beating back among the promontory of the dead.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: Regroup! The Spartans pull into one another, gathering force, streaming into the Persians like a wall of intimidation. Astinos rages on, killing the dark figures without pause.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: Astinos. Astinos looks to his father across the salient, the Captain locks eyes with his son.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: On center. They share a moment of praise among this tenebrous day. From the middle of the fray a PERSIAN HORSEMAN, clothed in inked leather and iron mail, gallops through the melee. He raises his sword and with one arc.

dialogues.speaker: TIME SLOWS
dialogues.text: For all who see it, the combat stands still. It is no more brutal than the rest, only that it's one of their own, a Spartan. The Captain watches as Astinos is beheaded only a few yards away.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: Noooo! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Astinos' head falls to the muck and mire, another Persian | lifts the severed gift in his hands and tosses it up to the confident horseman. He holds the head above his and howls. A prize offering for Xerxes, he rides back towards the sea, never offering fight for a father's pain.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: They all die! The Persians retreat back, with their treasure, a young Spartan face. The Captain's rage rises; he runs after the force hacking into the backs of fleeing men.

dialogues.speaker: DILIOS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: The day wears on... We lose few, but each felled is a friend... or dearest blood, and upon seeing the headless body of his own young son the Captain breaks rank. He goes wild... blood-drunk. Dilios and Stelios follow him, allowing his frenzy to run its course until all the enemy life has been snuffed out. Finally a group of Spartans drag the Captain from the | field, his face twisted with grief, his tears etching | lines in the mix of blood and dirt on his face.

dialogues.speaker: DILIOS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: The Captain's cries of pain at the loss of his son are more frightening to the enemy than the deepest battle drums. It takes three men to restrain him and bring him back to our own. The day is ours. No songs are sung. The Persian camp goes deathly quiet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A wood fire burns in the corner, illuminating the simple mason and beam ceilings. Theron and Gorgo stand in 1 conversation. i :| i

dialogues.speaker: GORGO
dialogues.text: i I am not here for small talk, { Theron.

dialogues.speaker: THERON
dialogues.text: I am sure of that. You have never spared words with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: i

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Theron walks to a rimmed table, tanned cougar hide covering its base.

dialogues.speaker: THERON
dialogues.text: A drink? Gorgo studies his face and with a laugh.

dialogues.speaker: GORGO
dialogues.text: Is it poison? He lifts a high pitcher, inlaid of silver palmette rising from acanthus leaves.

dialogues.speaker: THERON
dialogues.text: I am sorry to disappoint you, my Queen. It's just water. He pours the water into two shallow bronze bowls, hammered with the images of a seated fox and hen. He hands the water to Gorgo.

dialogues.speaker: THERON
dialogues.text: I am told you are going before the Council.

dialogues.speaker: GORGO
dialogues.text: I am not seeking your advice, just your help in winning votes to send our Army north to their King. Theron turns to face Gorgo in the half-lit room.

dialogues.speaker: THERON
dialogues.text: Perhaps I could help. The two of | us standing together, the politician, the warrior, our voices as one, but what does your willingness prove? Gorgo takes a sip from the bowl and sets it on the near table.

dialogues.speaker: GORGO
dialogues.text: It proves that I care for a King who at this very moment fights for the water we drink. Theron nods in agreement.

dialogues.speaker: THERON
dialogues.text: True. But this is politics, not war. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He sets his water down and looks at the Queen.

dialogues.speaker: THERON
dialogues.text: Leonidas is an idealist. The Queen paces across the near window.

dialogues.speaker: GORGO ,
dialogues.text: I know your kind too well. You i send men to slaughter for your own gain.

dialogues.speaker: THERON
dialogues.text: Your husband, our King, has broken the laws. He has left without the council's blessings... I am simply a realist.

dialogues.speaker: GORGO
dialogues.text: You are an opportunist. And a bad one at that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Theron closes the distance to the Queen.

dialogues.speaker: THERON
dialogues.text: You're as foolish as Leonidas if you believe that men don't have a price in this world. All men are not created equal. The Spartan code reinforces this maxim, you silly little girl. | Without hesitation, Gorgo slaps Theron clean across his | face. He is unmoved by the blow.

dialogues.speaker: THERON
dialogues.text: i I admire your passion. But don't think that you, a woman, even a Queen, can walk into a council chambers and sway the minds of men. Regardless of what your king says, you have no power there. I own those chambers, as if they were built by these hands. He grabs Gorgo by the throat, she struggles for a moment under his power.

dialogues.speaker: THERON
dialogues.text: I could crush the life from you right now! Gorgo searching the room, nothing, to aid her plight. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: I
dialogues.text: i 1

dialogues.speaker: THERON
dialogues.text: You will speak to the council and your words will fall on deaf ears. You will receive NOTHING without me. Leonidas will have NO reinforcements and if by the Gods' grace returns, he will be jailed or worse. Gorgo looks at Theron in disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: THERON
dialogues.text: Do you love your Sparta? Gorgo's eyes lock with Theron as she -- GASPS for air.

dialogues.speaker: GORGO
dialogues.text: Yes. His grip tightens around her neck.

dialogues.speaker: THERON
dialogues.text: And your King?

dialogues.speaker: GORGO
dialogues.text: I do. Theron smiles again as he watches Gorgo squirm under his powerful grasp.

dialogues.speaker: THERON
dialogues.text: Your husband fights for his land, for his love. Theron releases his grip on the Queen's neck.

dialogues.speaker: THERON
dialogues.text: What do you have to offer Sparta?

dialogues.speaker: GORGO
dialogues.text: What does a realist want with his Queen.

dialogues.speaker: THERON
dialogues.text: I think you know. Gorgo trembles, knowing that this sacrifice is the one Theron truly wants. She lifts her hand and pulls at the soft lace that holds the dress at her neck. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: THERON
dialogues.text: This will not be over quickly. You will not enjoy this. I am not your KING! There are no tears. Gorge stands naked before Theron, as he begins to ravage her, she makes not a sound, not a move. She gives him anything and everything, but not her heart in the faint firelight of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A perimeter of tribes surround the sanctuary of their God, Xerxes. Foot soldiers sharpen their weapons near a stable of warhorses. Castaways and penniless slaves roam the night for their masters, a makeshift world of chaos at the edge of the sea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WE HEAR: The FAINT CRIES, erotic WAILS, with the SOFT DRUMMING. A goat-headed minstrel plays the sitar. Others smoke from pipes of octopus skin and listen to the reed instruments of the East. This is a different world. A world of fine silk walls, rugs from the Orient, soft pillows, towers of honeycombed candles. Incense burns and hangs in tooled copper baskets. A procession of slave girls, all near naked, sheer gauze and jeweled bodies, dance for Xerxes in the faint light.

dialogues.speaker: XERXES
dialogues.text: Your Gods were cruel to shape you so, friend Ephialtes. Under a canopy of soft light, Ephialtes moves from the shadows.

dialogues.speaker: XERXES
dialogues.text: But I am kind. Xerxes on a marble pedestal, adorned in rare diamonds and emeralds from lands far from where he now stands.

dialogues.speaker: XERXES
dialogues.text: Everything you could ever desire. Concubines of all shapes, colors and nations are brought forth for Ephialtes. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: j

dialogues.speaker: XERXES
dialogues.text: Every happiness you can imagine. Ephialtes squints his one blue eye at the spectacle.

dialogues.speaker: KERXES
dialogues.text: Every pleasure your fellow Greeks and your false Gods have denied you. The dancers writhe against Ephialtes' frame.

dialogues.speaker: XERXES
dialogues.text: I will grant you... for I am kind. Ephialtes wipes the drool, the sheer temptation from his lips and speaks.

dialogues.speaker: EPHIALTES
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: XERXES
dialogues.text: Embrace me as your King and as your God.

dialogues.speaker: EPHIALTES
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: KERXES
dialogues.text: Lead my soldiers to the hidden path that empties behind the cursed Spartans.

dialogues.speaker: EPHIALTES
dialogues.text: Yes. The dancers reach deeper into the heights of their tortured bodies.

dialogues.speaker: XERXES
dialogues.text: Your joys will be endless.

dialogues.speaker: EPHIALTES
dialogues.text: Yes. Xerxes opens his impressive arms, extending his jeweled hands to his Greek guest.

dialogues.speaker: XERXES
dialogues.text: You will create your destiny. The dancers have now thinned into the b.g. The MUSIC softens and DRIFTS AWAY. Now there is only the God King and the Quasimodo named Ephialtes. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: EPHIALTES
dialogues.text: I want it all... Land... Wealth.. Women... and one more thing. Ephiaites shuffles closer and opens his eyes wide for Xerxes to view.

dialogues.speaker: EPHIALTES
dialogues.text: I want a uniform. Xerxes folds his arms over one another and simply nods.

dialogues.speaker: XERXES
dialogues.text: Done. Ephiaites takes a deep breath, as if to breathe in his newfound wealth and treasures.

dialogues.speaker: XERXES
dialogues.text: You will find... I am kind... Unlike the cruel Leonidas who demanded that you stand. I require only that you kneel. And with those words, Ephialtes lowers his warped body, head following his hands, crumpling his weight down to both knees and bows before Xerxes without more celebration or thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The air rings as blacksmiths hammer blades, shields and spear tips for the next morning's contention. Leonidas pulls at his tattered cape, wanders the different campfires, watching his men's faces as they recover from the day.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: Dilios, I trust that scratch hasn't made you useless? Dilios crouches near the firelight, binding a crude bandage across his face and head.

dialogues.speaker: DILIOS
dialogues.text: Hardly, My Lord. It's just an eye. The Gods saw fit to grace me with a spare.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: My Captain? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: he

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Dilios rises and points to a sole campfire raging atop the ridgeline.

dialogues.speaker: DILIOS
dialogues.text: He curses the Gods and mourns alone. Leonidas nods quietly. Daxos rides into the Spartan encampment.

dialogues.speaker: DAXOS
dialogues.text: Leonidas, we are undone! Daxos dismounts, dropping the leather reins and without haste, covers the ground to Leonidas.

dialogues.speaker: DAXOS
dialogues.text: Undone I tell you! Daxos' eyes dart around the blackness beyond the firelight searching nervously the high cliff face and then returns to the King.

dialogues.speaker: DAXOS
dialogues.text: Destroyed. Leonidas has heard enough and barks out.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: Calm yourself. Daxos breathes deep and returns to his frightened rant.

dialogues.speaker: DAXOS
dialogues.text: A hunchback traitor has led Xerxes' Immortals to the hidden goat path behind us! The Spartan warriors straighten to this news as if ice has been run through their veins.

dialogues.speaker: DAXOS
dialogues.text: The Phocians you posted there were scattered without a fight. This battle is over, Leonidas. The Spartan King turns his back to the Arcadian.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: This battle is over when I say it is over, Daxos. Daxos continues to plead his case. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DAKOS
dialogues.text: By morning, the Immortals will surround us. The Hot Gates will fall.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: Spartans! Prepare for Glory! His Warriors have already begun preparing their weapons, armor and bodies for their shared fate.

dialogues.speaker: DAXKOS
dialogues.text: Glory? Have you gone mad? There is no glory to be had now. Only retreat or surrender or... death! Leonidas turns now to face the man who breeds doubt into the minds and hearts of his tribe. He glares into the eyes of Daxos.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: That's an easy choice for us, Arcadian. The King snaps his response with a steel of character even his enemies admire.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: Spartans never retreat! Spartans never surrender! Go spread the word! Let every Greek assembled know the bald truth! Let each among them search his own soul! And while you're at it... search your own. Stelios holds out the reins for Daxos’ horse.

dialogues.speaker: DAXKOS
dialogues.text: My men will leave with me. Daxos takes the loose reins in his hands.

dialogues.speaker: DAXOS
dialogues.text: Godspeed, Leonidas. The King is ummoved, and watches Daxos leap to the bare back of the pearl mare. Daxos heels the horse's side and disappears. Leonidas wastes not a moment and turns to his men.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: Children, gather around. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Stelios, Dilios, and Spartan warriors close in around their King.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: The Gods favor us. The Spartans roar out.

dialogues.speaker: SPARTANS
dialogues.text: Haaawooo!

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: Tomorrow, we light a fire that will burn in the hearts of all free men for all the centuries yet to be. The Spartans stomp the dry earth in unison, like a thundering pulse that runs through them all.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: No retreat... No surrender! This is Spartan law!

dialogues.speaker: SPARTANS
dialogues.text: Haaawooo! Leonidas moves in front of his men, reaching into their will and stirring their souls.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: And by Spartan law we will stand and fight and die! The warriors erupt, POUNDING their shields and raising their weapons towards the star-filled blanket above.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: The law. We do not sacrifice the rule of law to the will and whim of men. That is the old way. The old, sad, stupid way. The way of Kerxes and every creature like hin. Leonidas stands clearly in front of his brave men. His red cape lifts and floats with his every impassioned gesture. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: A new age has begun. An age of great deeds. An age of reason. An age of justice. An age of freedom. And all will know that three hundred Spartans gave their last breath to defend it!

dialogues.speaker: SPARTANS
dialogues.text: Haaawoo! From the blackest corner of the Spartan encampment... WE SEE: Leonidas' Captain appear, like a specter of death, his face and body smeared and covered, a mixture of ash, soot, and his son's blood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My friend. Leonidas reaches out to his Captain.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: I have lived my entire life without regret until now... It is Not that my child gave his life for his country. The Captain shakes his head slowly from side to side.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: Oniy that I did not tell him that I loved him the most, that he stood by me in honor... that he * was what is best in me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leonidas embraces his friend for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: My heart is broken for your loss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Captain nods softly.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: i Heart? I have filled my heart | with hate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: : The Captain looks into the flickering flames and back t his King.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: Good. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The Captain's eyes search deep into the valley, to the Persian camp below.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: Dilios, let's take a walk. Dilios nods his bandaged head.

dialogues.speaker: DILIOS
dialogues.text: Yes, My Lord.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dilios and Leonidas stand on a rocky patch of land away from the rest. Dilios is confused, his face pleading with his King.

dialogues.speaker: DILIOS
dialogues.text: But... but... sire... I am fit. I am ready for combat.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: That you are, one of the finest. But you have another talent unlike any other Spartan. You will deliver my final orders to the council with force and verve. Tell them our story of honor, duty, glory, and freedom. Make every Greek know what happened here, you will have a grand tale to tell. Dilios feels the weight of responsibility. His King's eyes are bright and clear. .

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: A tale of victory.

dialogues.speaker: DILIOS
dialogues.text: Victory? Dilios shakes his head slightly. Leonidas lets the moment stretch, then smiles at him. He squeezes his shoulder and, nodding, lets him go.

dialogues.speaker: DILIOS
dialogues.text: Yes, My Lord. Dilios begins to turn and then slows.

dialogues.speaker: DILIOS
dialogues.text: Sire, any message...? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: For the Queen? Leonidas is gone. Transported by thought, across time, set free from the bonds of politics and responsibility. For a fleeting moment he is just a man, separated by circumstance from his reason for living, His Love. His Queen. Leonidas takes hold of the wolf tooth, pulls the worn leather necklace over his tired head and hands it to Dilios without a word.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: No... none that need be spoken. The storyteller turns, then leaves his King alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A false dawn comes slowly, faint blue rising along coastline. Dilios has gathered his shield and helmet, cape and sword. He begins to walk back through the Hot Gates and away. He is surrounded by Arcadians, Thespians, Phocians, Free Greeks all. They mutter as they go.

dialogues.speaker: DILIOS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: A handful stay. From a small rise, red capes and bronze shields watch as the Greeks abandon the Hot Gates.

dialogues.speaker: DILIOS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Thousands leave. Dilios can feel the eyes of his fellow Spartans and chances a look over his shoulder at his Spartan brothers, silhouetted against the morning sky.

dialogues.speaker: DILIOS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Only one looks back. The retreating Greeks continue.

dialogues.speaker: DILIOS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Only I. WE SEE: Dilios turn, within the river of men leaving the Hot Gates. He is near the end of the columns which wind away through the canyon. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Leonidas steps slowly through his men. All eyes on their Greek comrades disappearing into the pass. The Spartan King turns back to his men, they stand in silence. 300 SPARTANS. The morning sun just breaking in the East making them backlit. Capes glowing like hot coals.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: Spartans! WE HEAR: The collective battle cry.

dialogues.speaker: SPARTANS
dialogues.text: Haaawooo! Angry, deep and full of reverence for their King.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: Ready your breakfast and eat hearty... Leonidas raises his spear and bares his teeth.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: For tonight we dine in Hell!!!! 300 spears are thrust towards Heaven, helped up by a cry of defiance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WE HEAR: The chatter and conversation of the assembled. OLD SPARTAN WARRIORS, turned from using war to using words. A transition few are good at, but all carry its burden and responsibility. WE SEE: Gorgo entering from the carved penetralia. She walks alone into the acriform, chin lifted, hair braided, head high before the Spartan lawmakers. The ADVOCATES, STATESMEN, and PARTISANS settle into primitive seats that coil around the stone floors, thrusting forth a stage for the Queen to offer her words.

dialogues.speaker: LOYALIST
dialogues.text: May I give the floor now, to the wife of Leonidas and Queen of Sparta. The Loyalist bows slightly as Gorgo walks towards him. She nods and the Loyalist returns to his seat. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Gorgo stands, radiating not only her beauty but sheer internal strength. She scans the faces, appraising the crowd. She knows them all, her eyes even cross Theron. Gorgo shows not a trace of emotion as she clears her throat and begins.

dialogues.speaker: GORGO
dialogues.text: Councilmen, I stand before you not only as your Queen. She shifts into the amber light that now floods through the windows.

dialogues.speaker: GORGO
dialogues.text: I come to you as a mother. The chambers quiet to her voice.

dialogues.speaker: GORGO
dialogues.text: I come to you as a wife. Gorgo moves slowly on the stage.

dialogues.speaker: GORGO
dialogues.text: I come to you as a Spartan woman. She looks to Theron, locking eyes with him until he pulls his contact away.

dialogues.speaker: GORGO
dialogues.text: I come to you with great humility. Theron leans forward, listening carefully.

dialogues.speaker: GORGO
dialogues.text: I am not alone in this room. Gorgo looks again to Theron, she points, just past him to a STATESMAN in the seats to her left. Theron relaxes.

dialogues.speaker: GORGO
dialogues.text: You, your son fights at his King's side. The Statesman nods to his Queen. As she turns quickly to another.

dialogues.speaker: GORGO
dialogues.text: Have you forgotten your fine boy? A PARTISAN shakes his head softly, thinking of his young.

dialogues.speaker: PARTISAN
dialogues.text: No. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Gorgo turns again, using all caution with her words.

dialogues.speaker: GORGO
dialogues.text: I am not here to represent Leonidas. His actions speak louder than my words ever could... I am here to speak for all the voices that cannot be heard. Mothers, daughters, sons, fathers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gorgo takes a breath, centering her thoughts.

dialogues.speaker: GORGO
dialogues.text: 300 families that bleed for our rights and for the principles this very room was built upon. The Queen looks to the members of the council.

dialogues.speaker: GORGO
dialogues.text: You must not forget from where you came. All in this chamber once carried arms, to defend Sparta. You are men that now balance peace and war. That balance has been challenged. We are free only because of some fight to ensure it. i

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gorgo walks slowly, building her strength.

dialogues.speaker: GORGO
dialogues.text: We are at War, Gentlemen... We must send the entire Spartan Army to aid our King in the preservation of not just ourselves, but our children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Queen delivers with all her conviction and passion.

dialogues.speaker: GORGO
dialogues.text: Send the Army for the preservation of liberty... Send it for justice... Send it for law and order... Send it for reason... But most importantly send our Army hope. Hope that a King and his men have not been wasted to the pages of history. That their courage bonds us together. That we are stronger by their actions and that your choices today will reflect their bravery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: WE SEE: Men lean together, some whisper into each other's ears, confidences are passed freely among them. Theron watches as Gorgo has quickly made work of his room. He claps, slowly rising to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: THERON
dialogues.text: Moving, eloquent, passionate. Theron rests his hands and scans the faces in the chamber in silence.

dialogues.speaker: THERON
dialogues.text: Why do you waste the time of these important men? Gorgo turns to the arrogant voice.

dialogues.speaker: GORGO
dialogues.text: Do we waste your time? Each man in this room is no more important than the next.

dialogues.speaker: THERON
dialogues.text: You insult the council, my Queen?

dialogues.speaker: GORGO
dialogues.text: That is not my intention.

dialogues.speaker: THERON
dialogues.text: What is your intention? Gorgo speaks to the seated audience with clear words.

dialogues.speaker: GORGO
dialogues.text: Only to remind us, that each day we determine our course.

dialogues.speaker: THERON
dialogues.text: Course?

dialogues.speaker: GORGO
dialogues.text: Yes. These days are men's true riches. And they're being fought for at this very moment as we choose words. A STATESMAN rises and calis out.

dialogues.speaker: STATESMAN
dialogues.text: Your husband has brought war upon us! Gorgo shakes her head. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: i i

dialogues.speaker: GORGO
dialogues.text: You are wrong. Xerxes brought it forth, and before that, his father Darius at Marathon. The Persians will not stop until the only shelter you will find is rubble and chaos. Theron begins to walk down to the stage floor.

dialogues.speaker: THERON
dialogues.text: This chamber does not need a history lesson. Gorgo watches carefully as he descends the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: GORGO
dialogues.text: Then what is the lesson you would like to leave? Theron presses on.

dialogues.speaker: GORGO
dialogues.text: Shall we begin to enumerate all of them? Honor. Duty. Glory. Theron takes the stage from the Spartan Queen.

dialogues.speaker: THERON
dialogues.text: You speak of honor, duty and glory. What of Adultery? His voice BOOMS out into the chambers and a hush is leveled onto the listeners. Gorgo's eyes wide, stunned by his treachery.

dialogues.speaker: LOYALIST
dialogues.text: How dare you speak out in such a manner.

dialogues.speaker: THERON
dialogues.text: How dare I? Gorgo studies the room, quickly searching out friend or foe.

dialogues.speaker: THERON
dialogues.text: Watch her carefully, she is a trickster in true form. He narrows his attack. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: THERON
dialogues.text: Do not play with the members of this sacred room, my Queen. Just hours ago you lay with me. The chambers go wild at his telling.

dialogues.speaker: THERON
dialogues.text: I have your scent on me still. i

dialogues.speaker: LOYALIST
dialogues.text: This is an outrage! Two armed Spartan warriors now appear from a depression of the antechamber and flank Gorgo's left and right sides.

dialogues.speaker: THERON
dialogues.text: You look shocked. A bribe of flesh I was given while her husband promotes anarchy and war.

dialogues.speaker: GORGO
dialogues.text: I... you...

dialogues.speaker: THERON
dialogues.text: Words escape even the cleverest tongue, my little whore Queen. Gorgo's eyes burn with fire fed from the pit of her stomach.

dialogues.speaker: GORGO
dialogues.text: You... bastard. The Spartan guard grabs her just as she swings.at Theron. Missing him, she spits in his direction.

dialogues.speaker: THERON
dialogues.text: What Queen-like behavior. They hold her back, as she pulls at their arms, struggling to free herself. The room watches, frozen by the spectacle before them. aecsngoets

dialogues.speaker: GORGO
dialogues.text: You will soon feel nothing!

dialogues.speaker: THERON
dialogues.text: Remove her from the chamber before * she infects her son with her inglorious and shabby self. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Gorgo throws one of the guardsmen off her, spinning behind the other she draws his short blade, kicking him clear and with one quick step buries the blade deep into Theron's midsection.

dialogues.speaker: GORGO
dialogues.text: I am a Spartan Queen, need I remind you. Theron buckles, his weight brought forward onto Gorgo's bloody hands, still holding the blade. She cuts across his waistline and from beneath his elaborate frock... WE SEE: Persian gold pieces fall and dance onto the floor, Xerxes' face forged clearly upon them for all to see.

dialogues.speaker: GORGO
dialogues.text: It seems every man does have his price! Gorgo leans down and whispers softly into Theron's ear.

dialogues.speaker: GORGO
dialogues.text: When your bones are dust, my son will be King. She twists the short blade deeper into Theron.

dialogues.speaker: TIME SLOWS
dialogues.text: Their eyes lock.

dialogues.speaker: GORGO
dialogues.text: This will not be over quickly. You will not enjoy it. She remembers his cruelty.

dialogues.speaker: GORGO
dialogues.text: I am not your Queen. With those words she twists the blade out. Theron falls into a pile of his own blood and entrails. The Council members stand around her, some sift through the Persian gold, nodding at the traitor's death. But most stand in awe and admire their Queen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Persian archers climb down the steep cliff faces and settle their bodies in perfect positions to attack. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: WE SEE: The Spartan Phalanx solidify. Leonidas’ eyes searching, he listens for the coming Persian force and suddenly they appear. Led by Immortals. Hundreds of them surround what is left of Sparta's finest.

dialogues.speaker: PERSIAN GENERAL
dialogues.text: My compliments and congratulations. You have surely turned calamity | into victory. The PERSIAN GENERAL steps forward.

dialogues.speaker: PERSIAN GENERAL
dialogues.text: Despite your insufferable arrogance, the God King has come to admire Spartan valor and fighting skill. The Persian columns build behind each other.

dialogues.speaker: PERSIAN GENERAL
dialogues.text: You will make a mighty ally.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leonidas says nothing as Ephialtes pushes his way through the Immortals and faces his once King.

dialogues.speaker: EPHIALTES
dialogues.text: Yield, Leonidas. Use your reason. Think of your men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence, save the heartbeat of the Spartans to his back.

dialogues.speaker: EPHTALTES
dialogues.text: I beg you. Now carried on the back of Persian slaves, Xerxes and his throne are brought forth for the Spartan line to see.

dialogues.speaker: PERSIAN GENERAL
dialogues.text: Listen to your fellow Greek. He can attest to the divine one's % generosity. Despite your several 4 insults. Despite your horrid | blasphemies. The Lord of Hosts is i prepared to forgive all... and 2 more, to reward your service. Xerxes' throne rests completely and the Persian Lord sits knowing after days that he has the upper hand.

dialogues.speaker: PERSIAN GENERAL
dialogues.text: You fight for your lands...? Keep them. i (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The Persian force continues to build on the horizon. Now thousands are displayed and rest at Xerxes' command.

dialogues.speaker: PERSIAN GENERAL
dialogues.text: You fight for Sparta...? She will be wealthier and more powerful than ever before! Leonidas and his men are still, a solid wall of ragged warriors.

dialogues.speaker: PERSIAN GENERAL
dialogues.text: You fight for your kingship? You will be proclaimed warlord of all Greece. Answerable only to the one true master of the world. Xerxes waits the Spartan reply, both leaders defiant in their posture.

dialogues.speaker: PERSIAN GENERAL
dialogues.text: Leonidas, your victory will be complete. If you but lay down your arms and kneel to Holy Xerxes! The Spartan Phalanx is unmoving. Weapons tuned towards the Persians' divisions. They wait, their racing hearts, listening for Leonidas, his words, the fuel to their will.

dialogues.speaker: ELASHBACK
dialogues.text: Snow falls suspended by stretching time. The black paws of the wolf move slowly through the light snow. The young Leonidas, fearless, raises his sharpened stick into a fighting stance. The wolf narrows its red eyes, saliva running across its fangs.

dialogues.speaker: DILIOS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: It has been more than forty years since the wolf and the winter cold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seagulls hover on ocean breeze. Delicate feathers ripple with the wind. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DILIOS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: And now as then, it is not fear that grips him, only a restlessness. A heightened sense of things. The pitted and dented surface of the King's helmet. A bead of sweat rolls down Leonidas' neck. The hem of his tattered crimson cape pushed lightly by the wind, brushing a pattern into the sand at his feet.

dialogues.speaker: DILIOS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: The sea-borne breeze coolly kissing the sweat at his chest and neck. Gulls cawing, complaining even as they feast on the thousands of floating dead. 10,000 arrows shiver under the tension of drawn bows. The razor teeth and black eyes of the Immortals fight and jostle to lower spears and draw sabers, barely able to contain their bloodlust.

dialogues.speaker: DILIOS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: The steady breathing of the 300 boys at his back... ready to die . for him without a moment's pause. Every one of them... WE MOVE ACROSS the battered shields of the 300. Clear eyes peer from bronze helmets.

dialogues.speaker: DILIOS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: . ready to die. Finally Leonidas exhales deeply and slowly reaches for his helmet. The Persian General watching, under growing tension. Xerxes rising from his throne to better see his enemy's surrender.

dialogues.speaker: DILIOS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: His helmet is stifling... Leonidas' helmet strikes the ground bluntly.

dialogues.speaker: DILIOS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: - his shield is heavy. Leonidas shrugs off his SHIELD and it RATTLES to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: PERSIAN GENERAL
dialogues.text: Your spear. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Leonidas lets his gaze run along the length of his spear past its ragged tip, past even the Persian General to the hunched figure crouching among the legs and shields of the Immortals.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: You there, Ephialtes. The misshapen eye darts to avoid the King's gaze, then chances a look to Leonidas. The two hold each other's stare for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: May you live forever. The moment is broken.

dialogues.speaker: PERSIAN GENERAL
dialogues.text: Your spear, Leonidas. The Spartan King looks back down to his hand, clenched around the weapon. He slowly opens his hand and looks back at the Persian General, letting the SPEAR fall, landing with a dusty CLANK! He looks one last time to Xerxes standing atop his golden litter. Behind 10 rows of his bloodthirsty Immortals. Noting the wind as it dances with the black banners at the back of Xerxes' throne. WE SEE bronze strike the earth as Leonidas falls to his knees. His hands go to the rocky soil just in front of him. His head slowly bowing, his eyes close.

dialogues.speaker: ELASHBACK
dialogues.text: Leonidas and his son compare the size of their hands. The King's rough palm is barely covered by the entire soft hand of his son. The boy laughs. His eyes smiling. Soft light moves through leaves, laughing with the boy as he marvels at his father's hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gorgo sleeps in waist-high golden hay. Leonidas with the stem of yellowed grass lays next to her. He traces the contour of her cheek, she slowly swats at it. He continues down her neck, his eyes lost in her form. The nape of her neck, her collarbone, her black hair curly against the golden stalks of hay. Tickled, she opens her groggy eyes and seeing her husband, softly smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leonidas, eyes closed, lets the faintest of smiles fade, then with head still down, calls...

dialogues.speaker: STELIOS
dialogues.text: From behind the kneeling King, shields part and in two crushing strides, young Stelios leaps, spear in hand, from the cover of his Spartan brothers. Planting a foot on his King's back, he flies at the Persian General and, still in the air, he thrusts. Ribs part and sever. The exiting blood sprays into the eyes of nearby Immortals as the General withers under the blow. Leonidas snatches his own spear and, rising, loads for a mighty throw. Xerxes bares his teeth in anger at the defiant King.

dialogues.speaker: XERXES
dialogues.text: Slaughter them!!! The air goes thick with wood shafts, feathers and steel.

dialogues.speaker: TIME SLOWS
dialogues.text: Leonidas does not see the black banners at the back of Xerxes‘ throne fall with the lull in the wind. The only sound is that of countless ARROWS POUNDING into BRONZE SHIELDS, like hard rain on a metal roof. Through this barrage, Leonidas gathers every ounce of his strength.

dialogues.speaker: DILIOS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: His helmet was stifling. It narrowed his vision... WE SEE: The Ring's eyes. Calm, cold and focused on his target.

dialogues.speaker: DILIOS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: - and he must see far. The Spartan King's muscles pull the spear forward as around him the Persian spindles cut his children down.

dialogues.speaker: DILIOS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: His shield was heavy. It threw off his balance. Leonidas lets his spear fly as one after another, arrows settle into hin. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DILIOS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: His target is far away. The spear of Leonidas flies against the current of incoming arrows as the King cries out!

dialogues.speaker: XERXES... DIE
dialogues.text: Dozens of arrows strike Leonidas at once. His men fall fighting. Leonidas draws his sword, struggling to free it from its sheath as arrow after arrow punches through limb and sinew.

dialogues.speaker: DILIOS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: The old ones say we Spartans are descended from Hercules himself. Leonidas falis back upon the body of another of his fallen brothers. He then pushes himself back to his knees.

dialogues.speaker: DILIOS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Bold Leonidas gives testament to our bloodline. His roar is long and loud. As Leonidas cries out in his glory, his spear travels silently out, away from the dying Spartans. TIME SLOWS. It soars in a straight line. Its shadow snaking up the ornate carpet of Xerxes' throne. The God King does not move. He can only watch, wide-eyed as the spear of Leonidas, thrown as his final act, grazes his cheek. A small spray of blood flies from Xerxes' face as the spear sticks into the back of the golden throne. The assembled host of Persian generals gasps in awe at the sight of the God King's spilled blood, divine no more. The unquenchable bloodlust of the Immortals rises to a fevered pitch as they bring to bear their entire arsenal of spears, arrows, swords and lances against the Spartans who fight on as they die. The Captain. charges forward out of ranks. Dozens of arrows finding their mark in his back and chest. Yet, he does not fall. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Leonidas watches helpless as one of the Immortais plunges a spear into the Captain's chest. The Captain takes hold of it, dropping shield and spear, pulling it into his own body, moving close to the Immortal who wields it. As life ebbs from him, he grips the Immortal's skull and twists it, snapping the neck with an audible crunch. The Immortal falls beneath him. The Captain rolls off, i snapping the arrows that protrude from his body. :

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: Astinos... He exhales deeply and dies, his son's name still on his lips. Xerxes puts a hand to his bleeding face. Overcome, he collapses to his throne. Leonidas struggles to reach Stelios. The two fight on... side by side with broken blades and useless shields, hacking at the relentless Immortals. WE HEAR: A black and gold turbaned herald... TRUMPET! Through a horn of human bone, signaling the : Immortals to fall back so as not to be cut down by their own archers. Exhausted and mortally wounded, Stelios and the King crawl back among the handful of still living Spartans. Endless scores of fresh archers take up positions on hillside and boulders, surrounding on all sides that which remains of the Intrepid 300. Stelios, through labored breath, his own blood running into his eyes, calls to his King. Just feet away.

dialogues.speaker: STELIOS
dialogues.text: My King.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Each breath pain rising from within hin.

dialogues.speaker: STELIOS
dialogues.text: It's an honor to die at your side. i Leonidas rises looking down at Stelios.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: It’s an honor to have lived at yours. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Countless archers bend bows as if the very earth around the dwindling Spartan ranks was not made of stone, scrub grass and cliff, but of bent ash, cat gut, and hungry iron arrow tips. We are CLOSE TO Leonidas' lips, chapped and splattered with dark blood. A Persian Commander nods to the herald. He inhales deeply. Leonidas is calm. His voice lowers.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: My Queen... my wife. WE HEAR: The HORN. Nesting birds take flight. Leonidas' lips move, a whisper of reverence.

dialogues.speaker: LEONIDAS
dialogues.text: My love... The arrows are released as one. The lethal dark cloud races across the rugged and bloody battlefield. Stelios narrows his eyes and with his last breath, stands next to his King. The ARROWS STRIKE a single... DRUM STROKE. BLACKNESS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the edge of the city. Gorgo stands waist~deep in the amber hay, it moves around her, pushed and slanted by a late summer wind. The sun is low in the West. Gorgo has come to this spot many times. Her brown eyes scanning the low hills. A figure appears at the edge of the field. The light coming over his back as he moves toward her. His shadow loosely moves among the hay before him. He walks. WE SEE: Dilios, his battered form, a testament to his valor. Shield rutted and the cut bronze has peeled back to reveal oak. His helmet is dented and tarnished. The dried blood on his makeshift eye patch. He stands before his Queen alone. Her eyes a thousand questions. They share a silent moment of grief. She knows without word the fate of her husband. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He does not reach into pocket or pouch. He simply raises his hand from his hip, turns his palm upward and opens it. There resting in the cut and calloused hand of Dilios is the wolf tooth necklace. Gorgo holds out her hands. Eyes welling. Dilios lets it fall then closes his hands around hers. He squeezes gently. She looks down and away. Her face binding in grief. Dilios watches her, feeling his own pain. He moves on, leaving her framed by the waving grass. Her body begins to shake. She drops to her knees. Her nose runs, all her Spartan reserve lost. WE SEE: A boy hurrying past Dilios without a look. The King's son, Pleistarchos, runs, hay brushing at his knees as he rushes to his mother's side. Dilios turns watching from a distance. Pleistarchos reaches her, they embrace. Gorgo's face red and wet with tears as she looks at him, seeing her husband's eyes. Her love. She then takes the leather necktie and places it over her son's head. He bows, letting it come to rest at his chest His small fingers touching it. Pleistarchos puts his hand on his mother's face, gently wiping away her tears. Dilios watches as the dark figures in the bright hay embrace again. He nods silently to himself and turns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dilios still bloodied from battle, chin down, brow knitted. Lives each moment again. His voice ECHOING from the stone walls. Dilios stands at the center of the round room. WE MOVE: WITH him, rotating slowly.

dialogues.speaker: DILIOS
dialogues.text: Remember us... as simple an order as a King can give. Remember why we died. The faces of the Spartan gallery are riveted. This is the very reason why this room was built.

dialogues.speaker: DILIOS
dialogues.text: For he did not wish tribute or song, nor monuments, nor poems of war and valor. His wish was simple. Remember us... He said to me... that it was his hope should any free soul come across that place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WE MOVE: SLOWLY ACROSS a still life of death. Spartan brothers all lay beset with arrows too numerous to count. And as we hear Dilios' voice, we are reminded it is his voice which has lead us all along.

dialogues.speaker: DILIOS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: In all the countless centuries yet to be... oie WE SEE: Spartan after Spartan, eyes locked in death stares, laying atop one another. Stelios. Dozens upon dozens of arrows pin him to the shield he lays upon. One clear eye peers towards the sky. The other put out by Persian spindle.

dialogues.speaker: DILIOS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: + may all our voices whisper to you from the ageless stones. At the center of this scene of heroic dead, arms outstretched upon the blood-soaked ground in a Christ- like pose, lays the Spartan King. WE MOVE: SLOWLY UPWARD, LOOKING DOWN ON Leonidas, his body riddled with arrows.

dialogues.speaker: DILIOS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Go tell the Spartans, passerby... We CONTINUE TO RISE UNTIL... WE SEE: Ali of the falien 300.

dialogues.speaker: DILIOS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: .. that here by Spartan law we lie!

dialogues.speaker: DILIOS' FACE
dialogues.text: WE SEE: The wounds have heeled. He wears a leather eye patch. Firelight and the blue ambience of dawn mix.

dialogues.speaker: DILIOS
dialogues.text: And so my King died, and so my brothers died, barely a year ago...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All around the fire now stand, ready for war, capes the * color of blood, helmets and shields surround Dilios. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DILIOS
dialogues.text: Long I pondered my King's cryptic talk of victory. Time has proven him wise. Dilios begins to push through the Spartan warriors. They follow him from the fire.

dialogues.speaker: DILIOS
dialogues.text: For from free Greek to free Greek the word was spread that bold Leonidas and his three hundred, so far from home, laid down their lives not just for Sparta... WE FOLLOW: Dilios as he continues, the sea of Spartans making way for him as he moves slowly, taking time to clasp shoulder with hand, meeting eyes with nods.

dialogues.speaker: DILIOS
dialogues.text: ... but for all Greece and the promise this country holds. Shields are pulled aside and from a wall of fresh bronze, with dawn breaking in fingers of golden light, Dilios steps out in front of the Spartan line. He strides slowly with confidence along the barrier of shields. A forest of spears reach back into the distance, pointing skyward. A young SQUIRE hands Dilios his shield and spear. Eyes burn with battle lust as Dilios, never far from this tableau of Spartan bronze, continues.

dialogues.speaker: DILIOS
dialogues.text: Now, here on this rugged patch of Greece called Plataea, Xerxes' hordes face obliteration!!! WE HEAR: A collective cry answering Dilios.

dialogues.speaker: SPARTANS
dialogues.text: Haaawooo! A ery like rolling thunder spreading across the Spartan ranks. LOW FLUTES begin to play a haunting melody, joined by slow rhythmic DRUMMING of SPEAR on SHIELD. Dilios spins, pointing with spear out across the barren landscape that lay before him. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DILIOS
dialogues.text: Just there... the barbarians huddle. Sheer terror gripping tight. Their hearts with icy fingers knowing full well what merciless horror they suffered at the spears and swords of 300... a Dilios turns back to the line of men. It disappears int the distance on both sides of him.

dialogues.speaker: DILIOS
dialogues.text: .« yet they stare now across the plain at 10,000 Spartans commanding 30,000 free Greeks. Again he is answered with a thunderclap. | WE RISE: UP FROM Dilios to reveal a sea of men stretching out over the rolling hills. Thousands upon thousands of Spartan shields blaze with the rising sun.

dialogues.speaker: DILIOS
dialogues.text: The enemy outnumber us a paltry three to one. Good odds for any Greek. Dilios nods into his helmet. He takes hold of his spear and shield, melting back into the phalanx.

dialogues.speaker: DILIOS
dialogues.text: This day we rescue a world from mysticism and tyranny. We usher in a future brighter than anything we can imagine!! Dilios lowers his chin, gripping tightly the leather on his shield and as one in rhythm with the flutes, the spears of the Spartan war machine drop into position.

dialogues.speaker: DILIOS
dialogues.text: Give thanks, men, to Leonidas and the brave 300. | His eyes narrow, his teeth clench. Muscle and will become one.

dialogues.speaker: DILIOS
dialogues.text: To Victory!!! WE SEE: The Spartan wall of death coming in full run. Crimson CAPES SNAPPING behind them, the GROUND SHAKING. * (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Feet pound and churn the earth to dust and as it thunders TOWARD us, a razor-sharp spear tip just PASSES us, we TRAVEL DOWN its length TO the Hoplites' eyes, full of hate, glinting inside bronze, and then a shield FILLS OUR VIEW. FADE TO BLACK.
